column3: research
column4: viewing
column5: auto shows

column10: etc."

column2: 2004 3:37AM	stickguy	"I just love cars
column3: and hav esince I was a little kid. I had a subscription to Car and Driver and Motor trend when I was 10
column4: if that gives a clue.

column1: I have had an assortment of cars over the years
column2: but continue looking no matter how recently I bought. I don't usually buy right away
column3: but keep looking anyway.

column2: part addiction
column3: but I will look at anything
column4: anywhere. I usually get fixated on one thing for a while
column5: until the next set of wheels catches my eye.

column1: If NJ didn't have a 6% sales tax
column2: and rediculous DMV and insurance fees (and I had more garage space)
column3: I would probably have a revolving door of odd wheels going most of the time. My wife woldn't appreciate it
column4: but I consider that her failing
column5: not mine!"

column2: 2004 12:18AM	anonymousposts	"I recently tallyed up our purchases and came to a grand total of 34 cars in 9 years. I think I am addicted to car shopping period. I get excited when coworkers are looking for cars because I get to help them look and give them advice.

column2: 2004 2:32AM	anonymousposts	"CCB syndrome or does this make sense?

column1: I have a 04 EX-L Accord right now. I can buy a 97 Infiniti I30 for $4
column2: 000. Does it make sense to trade/sell the Accord for this car and save approximately $15
column3: 000 or should I keep the Accord and try to hang on to it for 10 years? The Accord is undoubtedly safer and gets better gas mileage. The insurance will probably be a wash .. the Accord is only $250 every 6 months. But is the Accord $15
column4: 000 safer and more economical than a nice
column5: clean I30?

column1: So is this common sense or CCB syndrome?

I should note that we will still have a 2004 Ody to use for family duty and a 03 Civic Si for commuter duty. The Accord is used for trips when one of us have the baby or short trips around town. The I30 would take the Accord's spot and be used for the same purposes."

column2: 2004 2:47AM	stickguy	"probably CCB
column3: although wether you save money depends on how reliable the i30 is.

column2: you will probably be better of fin the long run by keeping the Accord for 10 years
column3: instead of buying another car every 1-2 years. But
column4: that would be much less fun."

I got $2000 more in trade than I paid for the black Si and got the 02 Si for below invoice. Couldn't pass that deal up.

column1: Well unfortunately 3 weeks later some idiot in a Grand Am turned in front of me and ended up totalling my 02 Si. So I bought another one to replace that one. Well that Si was cursed. Within 6 months it had a new windshield
column2: it had rolled down my driveway and into the mailbox
column3: it rolled down a hill in a new housing development and ended up in a construction area (no serious damage in either incident) and a shopping cart got up close and personal with my rear quarter panel. SOOO ... we traded that for a 95 GS300 which my husband started driving and I took his 03 Accord coupe (by this time he had traded his blue 2000 SI for the Accord). Well .. after gas prices went up and we moved 15 miles further out my husband started missing the Si. So he traded our 97 Dakota (which we had acquired after the GS300 and the move) for a 03 Si and soon thereafter we sold the GS300 to a private party.

column1: And that's how you end up with 5 recent model Si's in 2 1/2 years."

column2: 2004 1:51PM	andre1969	"here's my list
column3: over the years...

column1: 1980 Malibu: Mom gave it to me (1987-1990)
1969 Dart GT: saw it at a Nissan/Saab/Oldsmobile dealer of all places
column2: fell in love with it
column3: and bought it. (1989-1992)

column1: 1957 DeSoto Firedome: I'd been lusting after a mid-late 50's DeSoto ever since I first saw a picture of one
column2: so when I found this one I just had to have it.(1990-today)

column1: 1968 Dart 270: bought to replace my '69 GT
column2: which got totaled when I got run off the road and hit a traffic light pole. (1992-today)

column1: 1969 Pontiac Bonneville: bought it from my cousin for $400. I should have known better! (1992-1996)
1982 Cutlass Supreme coupe: bought it for $800 when the Dart started nickeling and diming me to death. Only had 61K miles on it
column2: and was inspected. I figured it would be more reliable and get better gas mileage. It wasn't. And mileage wasn't that much better
column3: not enough to offset the fun factor of the much more powerful Dart! (1993-1994)

column1: 1967 Pontiac Catalina Convertible: saw it and had to have it. (1994-today)
1988 Chrysler LeBaron turbo coupe: bought it from my uncle when I got married. Along with the '82 Cutlass
column2: I'd say this was the biggest POS we had. I got divorced
column3: but got the last laugh because...I LET HER HAVE IT!!! (1995-1996)

column1: 1979 Chrysler Newport: For some reason I've always liked these things. I found this one in the junkyard...just came in
column2: started right up
column3: and hadn't been picked on yet. Bought it for $250. Odometer said 30K miles
column4: which I figured was about 130K miles
column5: given the condition of the interior. Well
column6: when I got the paperwork
column7: the previous owner had bought it about 10 years before
column8: with 105
column9: 000 miles. So in all probability
column10: it was more like 230
column11: 000! A nice little side benefit of this car
column12: in a twisted sort of way
column13: was that my family HAD been nagging at me to buy a newer car than that 300
column14: 000+ mile Dart I was driving! I don't think this was what they had in mind though. (1996-1998)

column1: 1986 Monte Carlo: Mom gave it to me
column2: with 179
column3: 000 miles on it. 3 months and 13
column4: 000 miles later
column5: I got T-boned while delivering pizzas. Wasn't TOO major of a hit
column6: but it bent the A-pillar and cracked the windshield
column7: and buckled the floor pan just a bit. Did most of my driving with this car
column8: because it got much better mileage and acceleated better than the Newport (1998-1998)

column1: 1989 Plymouth Gran Fury: this one was a former police interceptor from Richmond VA. It was also a sherriff's car
column2: so in addition to the high-performance equipment
column3: it was better equipped than most police cars
column4: with carpeting
column5: cloth seats
column6: a nice stereo
column7: power locks/windows/mirrors. I bought it because I wanted something newer than that Newport. Unfortunately though
column8: it wasn't any more reliable. (1998-today)

column1: 1985 Buick LeSabre Limited Collector's Edition: Don't laugh
column2: that was its name! Grandmom gave it to me when she couldn't pass the eye test for her license anymore. (1999-2002)

column1: 1967 Chrysler Newport: a 108K mile beater a buddy gave to me when his grandmother died
column2: and they just wanted it gone so that they could clean up her house and sell it. I only had it about 6 or 7 months. Decided to get rid of it when I bought my Intrepid
column3: and that decision was reinforced when the brakes went out. (1999-1999)

column1: 2000 Intrepid: bought it brand new. Originally I was just taking my uncle to the dealer to pick up his truck from servicing/repair
column2: but then he wanted to go look at the new cars. I had intended that day to ride up to another dealership that had a '95 Riviera for sale that I was interested in. But we never made it... (1999-today)

column1: 1979 Chrysler New Yorker 5th Avenue: I'd been going through R-body withdrawal ever since I got rid of my '79 Newport
column2: so when I saw this thing on Ebay
column3: I was able to satisfy that strange fetish... (2001-today)

column1: 1985 Chevy Silverado: Granddad bought it new. A few years after he died
column2: Grandmom gave it to my mother. She bought a new F-word 150 and then gave me the truck (2002-today).

column1: I think that's all of them. I used to live in a condo

column1: I don't get to pull the trigger very often
column2: but often enough to suit my never-ending need to get into something different. This last one was a bit premature and I have a few regrets
column3: until this last month when temps topped 100 and I reminded myself how feeble the AC was on the 318ti.

column1: 1984? Plymouth Horizon (Auto) - maroon and white. Crashed it my first day with a license. Fixed it
column2: drove it for about 7 months
column3: let my brother have it for three weeks when his truck died. That was the end of the Horizon...it died a horrible death two weeks later (engine seized)

column1: 1984 VW Rabbit Diesel (4-spd) - 64 hp and 350+ watts of stereo power. Removed the backseat to make room for the sub box enclosure. (!) Somehow I held onto that thing for almost 4 years. A mishap with a '68 Ford truck put it on the ""do not resuscitate"" list.
1986 Saab 900S (5spd) - Was my pride and joy. It was outfitted with most of the electronics from the Rabbit...had a sunroof
column2: was that cool Malachite green color. A short 15 months later
column3: I had invested $6k in repairs
column4: it needed another $3k and I dumped it for a $4k loss over purchase due to the repair needs. That one cost me big. (I loved that car...and it broke my heart.)

column1: 1986 Mercury Sable (Auto) - inherited from mom. It was a tank
column2: handle like crap
column3: had the digital dash and somewhat working AC. Drove it for almost two years until the bills were paid off from the Saab.

column1: 1995 Infinit G20 (5spd)- big incentives got me in...electrical issues and a job displacement ended up pushing me out. Sacrificed it to trade only 11 months after buying...
1996 Honda Civic HX Coupe (CVT) - never bonded
column2: but it helped me get through college. Soaked up many miles
column3: got good mpg
column4: the CVT was flawless
column5: no AC and only a moderate stereo. The window regulators failed twice in the middle of MN winters
column6: two years in a row. Was nearly totalled and them dumped when a Dodge Durango used MY brakes to come to a stop on the highway.

column2: almost sporty
column3: immediately upgraded the stereo to something decent. Burnt out the clutch
column4: but had no other mechanical weaknesses or gremlins. AC was too weak for AZ summers and the black paint looked like a 5-year old had rubbed sandpaper all over it. Sold it when I decided to go back to school for Masters...

column1: 2003 Hyundai Elantra (5spd) - reminds me of the Saab
column2: but not quite as ""snooty"" or as eager. Like the AC
column3: stereo is ok
column4: all the added features were hard to pass up and the warranty was just what a school-bound
column5: fixed-income guy needed...then I got a new job offer and put going back to school on hold.

column1: Now I am back shopping. I need to get a condo or house first...but then I am planning to trade up. Depending on the day

column3: 4-door sedans (G35
column4: used BMW 323
column5: Chrysler 300c
column6: VW Passat Diesel) to wagons (Passat
column7: Legacy) or who knows. The Audi A3
column8: Saab 9-2x
column10: and Pontiac Solstice have all had me considering a wait and see attitude. I can't afford to flip cars every year...but I would like to...it is hard not to.

column2: while my CCB is under control...I am always looking for ways to feed the habit
column3: like helping friends buy theirs
column4: test driving 6-12 cars a year
column5: and reading Edmunds site all the time
column6: Car and Driver and Road and Track...

column3: keep for three pattern.

2004 4:26PM	autonut	It all started when I was about 16 years old. My father and I started to search for a vehicle that would be my very first car. This was 1986. We were looking through the classified ads in the newspaper and found an ad for a 1966 Mercury Comet Capri. We went to look at it and I fell in love. It was a typical northern car with the rust and really bad bondo repair. I was still in love and it would be my project (or so I thought). My dad payed $400 and I payed $400 for grand total of $800 for the Comet. The Comet was Jamaican Yellow with Black interior. The interior was in great shape and it ran well with the 200 6 cyl. and automatic transmission. I did some work on the car in the summer and spring and it was stored away in a neighbors garage in the winter. My dad suprised me by having a friend of his take the car and re-do the body work and paint it was my 1987 Christmas gift. I couldn't wait for spring to finish it off and drive it. I was very happy with the Comet. Well I drove the Comet until 1988 or 89 when she met her demise with a jump of the RR tracks the unibody broke
column3: I couldn't find a safe fix and I needed wheels. I traded her in for a 1986 Ford F150 Flareside with a 6 cyl and a 3 spd on the column. I had it painted metalic blue. Now I will start the list. 1979 Ford Thunderbird. 1986 Dodge Omni GLH. 1991 Dodge Colt (My first New Car). 1969 Corvette. 1988 Mustang GT. 1995 Ford F150 S/C Flareside P/U. 2000 Chevrolet Cavalier Z-24 Convertable (Lemon Lawed). I don't remember the year of the next one it was a Chrysler Maserati TC (Piece of crap). 1998 Honda Civic EX. 1997 Ford Expedition. 2000 Ford Focus ZX3. 2001 Ford Ranger S/C Edge. 2002 Ford Ranger Reg. Cab. Edge. We also have a 2003 Honda Accord Cpe. I am now trying to hold back my urges for a new car. HELP!!!!!!

column2: in MD
column3: once a car hits 25 calendar years of age (for example
column4: on January 1
column6: all 1979 cars were eligible) you can get historic plates. Now with historic plates you don't need to get it inspected and you don't have to take it through the emissions test
column7: but you're not supposed to drive it all the time either. But with something that age
column8: it's not like I'm going to drive it everyday
column9: anyway!

column2: 2004 3:36PM	andre1969	"the ""small"" LTD of '83-86 (all big LTDs were called LTD Crown Victoria starting in 1983) was based on the Ford Fairmont.

column1: Initially the Fairmont was intended to compete with compact cars like the Chevy Nova and Plymouth Volare
column2: but GM threw everyone for a loop in the late 70's with downsizing. First they did it to their big cars in '77
column3: resulting in full-sized cars that were actually smaller on the outside and lighter than the typical 1977 intermediate (including GM's own) but were roomier inside.

column2: GM launched the Malibu and other downsized intermediates
column3: which were smaller and lighter than cars like the Nova and Volare
column4: yet roomier inside. They ended up about the same size as a Fairmont
column5: but heavier and a bit roomier inside.

column2: GM and Chrysler never really came out with ""true"" downsized intermediate platforms to compete with GM. Instead
column3: they just guzzied up their compact platforms and called them intermediates. The Ford Granada and Dodge Diplomat/Chrysler LeBaron were originally considered ""luxury compacts""
column4: but by around 1979 or 1980
column5: they were trying to pass them off as intermediates.

column2: the Granada was moved to the Fairmont platform
column3: and was passed off as an intermediate. Nevermind the fact that dimensionally
column4: it was identical to a compact Fairmont. Well
column5: for 1983
column6: the Granada was re-skinned to look much more modern and less neoclassic/formal
column7: and became the LTD. It was actually a good seller for Ford
column8: although did nowhere near the same volume of GM's A-cars such as the Celebrity. I think it did outsell the Malibu in 1983 though
column9: and was stronger in sales than Chrysler's RWD M-bodies or Chrysler's stretched out K-cars
column10: which were called the E-body (Plymouth Caravelle
column11: Chrysler E-class
column12: now there's an imaginative name
column13: Dodge 600).

column1: Most of the '83-86 LTDs came with either a 2.3 4-cyl (I think it was the Brazillian OHC Pinto engine) or a 120 hp fuel injected 3.8. Some early models had a 200 CID inline 6
column2: IIRC
column3: or a carbureted 3.8 that put out around 105 hp. And there was a propane 4 option.

column1: The 5.0 V-8 used in those LTD's was actually a special beast. It was supposedly only offered in '84-85
column2: in a model called the LTD LX. It had 165 hp (in the T-bird/Cougar and full-sized cars
column3: this engine only had around 140 hp
column4: but the Mustang GT by that time was probably up to around 200-220)
column5: quicker gearing
column6: and was supposed to be good for 0-60 in about 9 seconds. So it ended up being kind of an ""in between car""
column7: not quite something like a Monte Carlo SS or Buick Regal T-type
column8: but still a bit more than your everyday V-8 Bonneville
column9: Cutlass Supreme
column10: Monte Carlo
column11: Diplomat
column12: or Gran Fury.

column1: Maybe the LTD LX could be looked at as an early attempt at a domestic ""sports sedan""?"

2004 6:21AM	boaz47	"First remember if you look at some of the cars they weren't brand new when they were bought. Till I got my first Honda Si I can't remember taking a beating on a trade. If you buy a good used car that only need cosmetics and you fix it up and drive it a year or two you can often get your money back out of it. The SI was too easy to damage because the front clip tended to be a weak point if you raced them. One good smack into a hay bale and the Little SI was front end toast. Therefore when I traded it I took my first real loss. Not bad considering all the fun I had and what my son had done to the car but we didn't break even. Plus even the worst of the CCBs may have a favorite new car that they just have to keep toying with. Much like the Winchester Mansion if you do a little at a time you can effectively keep it a lot longer. One year a intake and exhaust. Next year a lowering kit and body kit. Next year some engine work. Then some bigger rims and low profile ultra high performance tires. Yes you may get another vehicle and even sell it while you work on your project but it doesn't have to be new just different. When I had my Camaro and was working on it I had two rather stock Suzuki Samari and a Mazda 626 that I did very little to. After I sold the Camaro I got another Suzuki and turned it into a rock crawler that would surprise a Jeep club. First gear low range was so low you could tie off the wheel and get out and walk faster than the car would go. Secondary cars don't have to cost that much nor do you concern yourself with trading them. And when you sell a project car you aren't trading for the most part. Somebody wants it and is willing to pay for it.

column1: Just as a word of caution. German cars can be expensive to fix after warrentee. I am not saying the Audi is a bad car but if you are into wrenching I would suggest you look into the cost of upkeep of an older German car. Not a slam nor am I dissing German cars. But ask others about repair and upkeep costs."

column7: if you fall asleep at the wheel
column8: your car will pull towards the shoulder instead of into oncoming traffic.

column4: most of the complaints are for one problem
column5: the car is junk""? What about this example: A car
column6: pick a car has 100 complaints per 1000 cars
column7: but the most any ONE problem appears is 10 out of that 100. Let's say the 300C has 80 complaints (both numbers totally made up) but the right pull is 40 of those 80 (as you said ""50% of the problems are related to pulling to the right""). What does that tell us? Nothing
column8: except to my eye

column2: but I know enough that if you throw out a number like ""50% of all complaints are x""--without telling me how many complaints there are overall OR what the average number of complaints are for other comparable vehicles
column3: then that ""50%"" stat is absolutely useless.

column2: Chrysler has recognized this as a problem (whether it's real or phantom) and provided a camber kit for dealers to install when customer complains. Several owners of 300s have stated on the main 300 board that yes
column3: they experienced the problem

column2: to make it sound like this quite possibly the most unreliable vehicle ever produced in its first year (words like ""ominous"") is unfair."

column2: 2004 11:17PM	nvbanker	"""Don't like the 300C? That's cool. Drive what you like and you're entitled to your opinion that the 300 is unreliable.""

column1: If you'll nose around a bit
column2: tornado
column3: you'll note that I like the 300C
column4: which is why I'm following it. I'm considering it as a new sedan in my fleet. I'm the guy who started the ""Chrysler Turnaround"" topic here. I'm just very concerned about the unusual number of posts of problems on the board
column5: and a very high number of them related to one issue. And it will likely put me off at least a year
column6: to see if they get it corrected. If they don't
column7: it will move me in another direction. That's what I use Edmunds for - research.

column1: Here's a recent exerpt from the 300C board - take issue with him
column2: why don't ya?

column1: #114 of 121 issue: pull to the right
column2: MAJOR CAR DEFECT by jeqq Jul 26

column1: I test drove two 300c's so far.
The second one initially had a immediate and rather severe pull to the right . However
column2: it had no pull for the remainder of a 30 minute test drive. I am positive
column3: and I repeat positive
column4: it was not due to road crown.

column1: I must say something that many of you may not like to hear. Even if this pull to the right is sometimes attributed to road crown
column2: (and again I am sure that was not the case with me) there is a major problem with this car. No car should ever handle like that if road crown exists. I could have had a car accident
column3: had I not been a good driver and concentrating on the road at that particular moment. I could see someone possibly having an accident if in that time frame they were not on top of their driving. All it would take would be one momentary lapse in concentration or your hand momentarily off the wheel and the car goes off the road
column4: or maybe something worse. We all have had these moments. I would not trust this car
column5: it could have a horribly deadly outcome.

column1: Has anyone else experienced this severe momentary pull to the right?

There is a post somewhere in the forums about a car accident attributed to this problem. I think 300c owners should start a class action lawsuit and have Chrysler recall and fix this steering problem immediately. Please do not wait until more cars are out there on the road.""

I'm very surprised y'all jumped all over me for mentioning this matter - I was recounting what I have read here only. Didn't realize we had some rabid Chrysler defenders here who can't handle a little concern over a new model. You'd think I have insulted the holy Honda or something."

column2: 2004 1:28AM	tornado25a	"""There is a post somewhere in the forums about a car accident attributed to this problem. I think 300c owners should start a class action lawsuit and have Chrysler recall and fix this steering problem immediately. Please do not wait until more cars are out there on the road.""

column1: I remember the ""post somewhere"". If you nose around a bit in the main 300 board
column2: you'll note that I (and several other posts) roundly criticized that post. The person was leaning over or down to check the e-brake (because the light came on)
column3: the car veered and the driver crashed into a pole. I'm sorry
column4: but THAT story was absolutely ridiculous--the rantings of someone who simply couldn't admit they screwed up while driving.

column2: I haven't driven a 300. I can't say whether that drift is there or not
column3: or how severe it is
column4: or if it's normal due to crowning. My main point
column5: in my prior post
column6: was missed entirely. There are NO reliable statistics that can be discerned from this message board. And looking at statistics--not what percentage of all problems reported are this problem or not what percentage of posts here report problems--RATHER--what percentage of ALL owners of this car have a problem or what percentage of ALL owners have drift?--is the only effective way to know how reliable this car is. Posts on the board are only anecdotal evidence of people seeking a way to complain.

column1: It's always worth repeating. In very few boards do the majority of the posters come on simply to say how great and problem-free the car is and then go away. Many regular posters will hang out because they are enthusiasts
column2: but I would say most people who come on briefly do so to simply complain. ""This is wrong
column3: that is wrong
column4: how do I fix it
column5: do you have the problem."" Posters on a message board are NOT a fair or representative sample of all 300 owners
column6: so it's IMPOSSIBLE to correctly draw any conclusions about the car's reliability from a message board.

column2: it's also worth noting that Chrysler came out with a fix for the problem and at least a couple posters who previously indicated they had the problem stated the car was perfectly fine after the camber kit was installed.

column1: If you find the 300 interesting and find it might be something you'd like to buy
column2: then I suggest you DRIVE one and see for yourself if it drifts or has problems."

column2: 000 miles and it was hard to not tell my true feelings. I should've given a Honda dealership a shot given my love/knowledge of the product but I never did and now I just don't want to deal with being in sales.

2004 8:56PM	corvette	"I don't have the paperwork with me
column3: but I know the payments are $464 per month plus tax on a 36 month lease with 0 down and 15
column4: 000 miles per year. I placed 5 security deposits of $500 each to buy down the money factor. The selling price reflected MSRP - the $1200 incentive - $500 dealer contribution. I know I left some money on the table
column5: but I really love the car. It has the cold weather package
column6: metallic paint
column7: and sunroof.

column2: here is my log of events surrounding the car's purchase...

column1: 7/29/2004 – I sign documents to lease the car and agree to pick it up July 30. I am offered gap insurance for $395 and a tire protection plan for $495. I only want the gap insurance
column2: but am offered both together for $495
column3: which I agree to. However
column4: the $495 is listed only as “tire protection plan” on the lease. Later
column5: I obtain information noting that they marked up the money factor and failed to inform me that I could significantly lower my payment by placing a security deposit. I also discover that all BMW Financial Services leases include gap protection at no additional cost (my lease was a BMWFS lease). Upon reviewing the tire protection plan
column6: I discover that the plan is fully refundable within 45 days. I decide to obtain a refund of the $495 charge through the insurance company instead of telling the dealership I no longer want it.

column1: 7/30/2004 – I inform the sales manager that there is something awry with the rent charge on the lease
column2: and quote the 0.0022 BMWFS lease money factor from Edmund’s. He admits that the lease charge was marked up
column3: that’s how the finance department makes money
column4: etc.
column5: and that the rate I noted would require one security deposit of $500. I reply that the *dealership* has made *plenty* of money on this sale
column6: and I would be willing to provide a security deposit but not a down payment. They agree to change the terms of the lease if I agree to pay the retail charge for acquisition fee instead of them giving it to me at cost. Because this is a significant net savings for me
column7: I agree. I get all the paperwork necessary for my father to cosign the lease
column8: and agree to return it by Monday.

column1: 7/31/2004 – My father comes into town to sign the paperwork (they wanted it notarized if he didn’t do it there)
column2: and all seems well. I note that I did not receive a copy of the lease paperwork
column3: they retained all the copies.

column1: 8/2/2004 – I receive a call from the sales manager explaining that they did not include sales tax in the lease due to a computer error. The docs need to be signed again
column2: and he wants to send a courier to do it. I explain that I will be returning to town Tuesday night
column3: and offer to handle all the transportation of paperwork myself. He explains that they will only count the sale in last month’s sales for my salesman if I don’t have to handle it
column4: supposedly to minimize my inconvenience. He offers me a free tank of gasoline. I reluctantly agree
column5: and he says that my salesman will be in touch. I tell my dad about the paperwork fiasco
column6: and he says he has no problem meeting the courier as long as it’s not tomorrow. I promise him not to have the courier sent tomorrow.

column1: 8/3/2004 – I receive two voicemails from my salesman and return them within an hour. He explains that he has already spoken with my father (the cosigner)
column2: and a courier is already on the way to obtain his signature at his place of work
column3: and estimates his arrival at my house at 1:00. At this point
column4: it is prudent to note that I never agreed to have the courier come on this date
column5: nor was I asked if I was available
column6: just told that he was on the way
column7: and I then agreed that I would be home around 1:00. At 2:30
column8: my dad calls and tells me he has not yet seen the courier. I tell him not to wait up
column9: he has to leave work by 3:00 and it’s not his problem. At 3:00
column10: he calls and tells me that he just met the courier. I explain that I have somewhere else to be
column11: and am walking out the door. He obtains the phone number of the dealership so that they can tell the courier to go back to Lexington. He calls the dealership and rips the salesman a new orifice after finding out that they sent a geriatric courier on a ~300 mile roundtrip with no cell phone
column12: also informs the salesman that he hopes they aren’t counting on a favorable satisfaction survey. I receive a voicemail at work from my salesman and return his call
column13: agreeing to come sign the papers before lunch tomorrow. He doesn’t tell me what transpired on the phone between Dad and himself. Later
column14: I receive another voicemail from my mother
column15: who informs me that she has signed the paperwork because the courier got all tee’d off that he had driven all that way for nothing. My father and I discuss the situation that night
column16: and agree to do nothing until we think about it. As far as I’m concerned
column17: I am not (yet) a lawyer
column18: but they have a falsified contract on their hands right now
column19: possibly signed under duress or coercion.

column1: 8/4/2004 – I have received no communication from the dealership
column2: presumably because they have written off my satisfaction.

column1: Did I mention that one of the worst things you can do to me is lie to me? And the two most common lies I am told which really
column2: really get under my skin are that someone will call
column3: and doesn't
column4: or that they will show up at a certain time
column5: and they don’t.

column1: I could have played dirty with them like they did with me. I could have tried to grind the price down after the fact by saying that my dad wouldn’t cosign because he says I paid too much. I could have done any number of other things that would land me a subject of discussion in the “Inconsiderate car buyers” topic. I suppose I could still
column2: like telling them that I no longer want the car due to their incompetence and deception.

column1: I might have expected this from a Hyundai dealer
column2: but I expect better of BMW
column3: the world’s greatest car company
column4: and its dealer network. The selling dealership was Don Jacobs BMW in Lexington
column5: Kentucky. They say they pride themselves on customer satisfaction
column6: but as far as I’m concerned
column7: they’re just another sleazy car dealership. For those of you who have made it this far

column2: long ago. She leaves early at least once a week and calls in once every two weeks. This creates more work for everyone. We have another girl who is late in excess of 2-3 times a week for no reason other than she overslept. More than once when she was scheduled to open the office she came in 2 hours late. Even though I am a supervisor of sorts I do not have the authority to do anything beyond pull them into the office and slap them on the wrist and say ""no-no"". column2: a 2-speed tranny isn't that bad if you have a big enough engine. I once drove a '58 DeSoto Firesweep that had a Mopar 350 (one of the earlier displacements of the 361/383/400 block
column3: and only offered in '58). It had a 280 hp setup
column4: and just a Powerflite 2-speed automatic. It didn't seem to hold that car back much at all.

column1: I also once drove a 1960 Olds Ninety-Eight hardtop coupe that *should* have had a 4-speed Hydramatic in it
column2: but I swear this one only had some kind of 2-speed! I only felt it shift once when accelerating
column3: and it seemed to be over-revving at highway speeds. But considering it had the interior of a 1960 Bonneville

column5: either! It also had a 394 (IIRC) 4-bbl
column6: so again
column7: it had no trouble accelerating

column1: Another area Chevy was really behind the times with was oil filters. Mopar went to a spin-on oil filter for 1958. I think Pontiac's first year was 1959. Well
column2: my '57 DeSoto still uses the old fashioned drop-in cartridge that's inside the metal cannister. There's the cannister
column3: filter
column4: a bunch of gaskets
column5: and it's all held together by a really long bolt
column6: and makes a big mess every time you change the oil. Well
column7: under normal circumstances
column8: a 1957 DeSoto oil filter would probably be almost impossible to find
column9: except for the fact that Chevy was still using that same part in 1967!"

2004 11:13PM	andre1969	"I got my bbq tool kit! It was a pretty nice setup for a free giveway
column3: and even came in a plastic case. Plastic
column4: that I might add had a nicer texture than the typical Chevy interior! :-P

column2: I drove a gray Magnum SXT. SXT's were all they had... the gray one
column3: a magnesium one
column4: and a silver one that had these $2200 bling bling 20"" rims and tires.

column2: but it wasn't without its faults. I don't like the transmission at all. At several points during acceleration
column3: it felt like it just disconnected from the car. Now I didn't go stomping it flat-out
column4: because it only had 17 miles on it
column5: but at one point
column6: accelerating onto US 301
column7: it got up to about 40 mph and then seemed to stop and level off at that speed for a second or two
column8: before accelerating further. Maybe you have to really stomp on it though
column9: to get it to shift through the gears more smoothly.

column1: And some things just take getting used to. Like the accelerator pedal; felt like it had too firm of a cable or something
column2: so you had to give it a little gas to get it to move. And don't even get me started on rearward visibility on this thing! Were station wagons that bad back in the day?!
though
column3: there was a lot to like. This sucker had plenty of legroom...I dunno where they get that 41.8"" figure in the official specs
column4: cuz I fit in this sucker better than I do my Intrepid. In some ways
column5: it almost feels like getting behind the wheel of my '79 NYer than it does any typical modern car. Storage space is excellent
column6: with a big bin in the center console (I liked the flip out cupholder on my Intrepid better than the stationary one here
column7: though)
column8: a big glove box
column9: and storage pockets in all 4 doors. My Intrepid only has them in the front doors. And
column10: while I don't smoke
column11: it was still a pleasure to see this car equipped with a cigarette lighter and ash trays! You had to pay something like $19 extra for that in the Intrepid.

column1: The interior definitely has a retro feel to it. The whole dash is big and blocky
column2: and bears a strong resemblance IMO to the dashboards that used to grace plenty of full-sized cars back in the day. And the door panels
column3: with their long
column4: simple
column5: linear designs and full-length armrests
column6: make me think of an old upper-level sedan like a '60's Electra
column7: Ninety Eight
column8: or NYer. Cheaper though
column9: because back in the 60's they hadn't learned how to use that much plastic yet!

column1: And overall the car had a nice
column2: solid
column3: stable feel. Doors had a nice feel when you closed them. If you really tried
column4: you could probably pull the interior apart with your hands
column5: but I have a feeling it would fight back! Nothing shook or rattled
column6: and it's amazing that a car with tires this low-profile can still ride this good!

column1: The one I looked at had a sticker of around $26
column2: 400. Sales guy said I could probably get it for $24K. The Magnesium SXT they had was a demo with about 400 miles on it
column3: and had leather. He said I could probably get it for less. Is that a good price for them? I didn't think they'd be marking that much off of them already!

column1: I guess it's a good thing I went down there in my NYer and not my Intrepid
column2: because it would've been awfully tempting to do a trade! Although I really do need to wait until I have the cash flow
column3: and spring for the Hemi! With a sunroof! ;-)"

column2: 2004 7:22PM	bryan	"My name is Bryan
column3: and I believe I may be a car junkie. I've read this entire thread
column4: and while I can't match some of the other ""junkies""
column5: I believe I have the qualities necessary for membership.

column1: My first car memory is riding as a three-year old standing up in the front seat of a new 1956 Pontiac (it was 1956 afterall!) with the neighbors who had ""adopted"" me as their own. I went everywhere with them
column2: as I found out later they could not have children
column3: and with two older brothers
column4: well
column5: my parents were most happy to parcel me out! I remember my ""adopted father"" Larry always pointing out new cars and I think he helped me start down the path...

column1: First car my parents owned I remember was 1957 Chevy BelAir pillarless? four-door in a beautiful copper/bronze-like color. I remember helping my Dad clean that car all the time (I was in charge of the whitewall tires!) It was totalled when hit from behind by drunk doing 50 mph while we were sitting at stoplight! We had just returned from my Dad's Navy tour in Hawaii--welcome to the mainland! First night off the ship we were all in the hospital--nothing serious thank goodness.
Replacement car was 1959 Chevy stationwagon in strange brownish color. Dad hated that car
column2: and he bought 1960 Mercury Comet four door right before we were shipped back to Hawaii. Had an AM radio
column3: and a heater! It was a light brown beige-like color.

column1: He traded that car for 1964 Comet right before we shipped back to the mainland. This car
column2: like the other Comet it replaced
column3: had just an AM radio
column4: but because it was bought in Hawaii
column5: had no heater. Upon return to the mainland
column6: we lived in SoCal (Port Hueneme navy base) but visited my brother who was Deputy Sheriff in Lockwood Valley
column7: where it could get very cold
column8: especially when the sun went down. Heater was installed after first visit!

column1: Then came the 1967 Chevy Malibu station wagon. I learned to drive on that car. I had three ""minor accidents"" in that car in first six weeks! Then they bought a 1970 Chevy Nova as a commuter car (living in MD by this time) with 3-speed on the column
column2: AM radio
column3: that's it. This car was a challenge for me as I learned that my left and right feet
column4: coupled with my right arm
column5: just do not work well together! Every car I have owned except one has been an automatic because of this. I will post my list IF accepted into this most prestigious forum."

The first opportunity turns out to be a 2000 Honda Civic Si. Boy is this car a screamer. Then we come across a ...

2000 Honda Civic Si .. this time in Electric Blue Pearl ... so we buy it with the intent of me driving the blue one and selling my black one. BUT I can tell from gee's face as we drive the blue one home that I will be lucky to see the driver's seat again. So he sells his 93 Civic and we keep both 2000 Si's.
We are now in summer 2002 and have the Lexus and the two Civic Si's. Well gee sees a lowered 02 Si hatchback on a website and wants to go take a look at one. We go to ""look"" and end up with a ..
2002 Honda Civic Si hatchback in white. Got the car for $1500 off invoice and got $2200 more than we paid for the black 2000 Si.
Some twit turns out in front of me in a Grand Am and totals the Si. So we buy a ...
2002 Honda Civic Si hatchback in white.

column6: oil
column7: and tires. I'm lucky in that I purchased an extended warranty which is still alive and has paid out much more than its cost.

column1: I generally wouldn't recommend a luxury car if you're sensitive to expensive repairs (unless you're a good shadetree mechanic and have a parts connection somewhere). Someone recommended a Lumina - I had a '96 LS (3.1L) for almost six years
column2: and it was a very reliable car
column3: if not a ""driver's car"" - kinda like an appliance car. The '95 through 2000 bodystyle is the more reliable one (and I'd avoid the first model year on general principle). and 2000 was fleet-only. The LTZ (loaded-up models) had the 3.4L ""Dual Twin Cam"" model for the first couple years
column4: then they put the 3800 in
column5: which may or may not have head gasket issues. I had the 3.1 (160 hp) and it never gave me any grief through 70+k miles (my wife's aunt in Michigan is driving it now
column6: has over 100k and has been ultra-reliable
column7: though the body is starting to rust out (rear quarter panels)). The interior (my LS was a rare model with ""leather"") is reasonably decent for a mid-90's GM product (had a rental Impala once and though the Lumina was better).

column1: The closest experience I had to no power steering was when the pump failed on my '68 Dart. Technically
column2: I guess that would make it WORSE than non-power steering

column5: and the cop that went out with him on the test had to drive my car back

column2: back in college I also knew a girl with an early 80's Dodge Colt

column4: and it didn't seem to be a problem.

column2: power steering was pretty much standard by the mid 70's. I think by '77
column3: it may have still been optional in something like a base Pontiac LeMans. Around that time
column4: wasn't Pontiac actually trying to under-cut Chevy in some markets
column5: while at the same time trying to reach into Buick/Olds territory?

column2: has anybody noticed
column3: in the few cars that still have them
column4: that it's almost like they go out of their way on purpose to make them as obnoxious as possible
column5: almost as if to punish you for not getting power windows? On most of my older cars with crank windows
column6: usually 2-3 turns of the crank and that window went down
column7: effortlessly and smoothly. And the crank knob was big enough to comfortably grab ahold of
column8: and usually positioned in just the right spot.

column2: they use some kind of tape-drive mechanism that's not nearly as smooth
column3: requires more effort to crank
column4: and what took 2-3 turns back in the day is now 4-5 or more. I guess if they made the window go down too quickly
column5: it would put too much stress on the tape-drive thingy. I've noticed that with power windows
column6: too. They don't drop or raise nearly as fast as they used to (presuming a fully functioning motor
column7: of course...as they age they do slow down sometimes) And then there's the crank. A cheap
column8: tiny
column9: flat plastic little thing that feels like it's going to break off in your hand. One reason they do that is for safety
column10: so it doesn't injure you as badly in an accident. But it's still annoying as hell! And instead of bludgeoning yourself on something that's metal (at least some of those older cranks did have a soft knob)
column11: you might be picking plastic splinters out of your body! And it also seems like they pick the poorest places to put the crank. Too far back on the door
column12: so when I reach for it
column13: it's almost like a contortionist routine."

Average purchase of car every 6 months (not NEW models) - Platinum Club Member (PCM-CCBA)

Average a new car every 24 months - Silver Savers' Member (SSM-CCBA)

2004 1:35AM	hammen2	"Actually
column3: I don't know if my GTO is a lemon or if the problems are the fault of the dealership's service department. I picked up the car on 8/27 and drove it for about 10 days
column4: putting approximately 800 miles on it. Noted three issues; some paint flaws on the rear quarter panel
column5: a lot of clunking from the rear suspension
column6: and a styrofoam-like squeak noise from the dash. I know it's a sports car
column7: but the ride quality was really harsh (""rides like an old truck"" was a common complaint of passengers :-).

column1: Dealership had the car for 2 weeks
column2: claiming to fix the rear noises by applying a TSB (only the bulletin came out in early April
column3: and my car was built in May after the VIN break). The TSB was supposed to fix the driveline hitting the chassis on hard acceleration - well
column4: I followed the break-in procedures for the car
column5: so it didn't have much hard acceleration and the clunking happened on any concrete road with expansion joints. Dealer did say they could see where the driveline was hitting the chassis...

column1: The bigger problem was the dash noise - dealer went 'round and 'round with GTO brand quality management
column2: eventually talking to ""Russell"" at the Holden plant in Australia. I got the car back for the weekend after two weeks in the shop (unrepaired
column3: dash partially disassembled and windshield removed and reinstalled). The squeak noise I had heard previously was replaced by a loud ""clunk"" noise
column4: most evident on turns. Dealer also scratched the rocker panel under the driver's side (tech kneeling on seat/steel-toed boots hit rocker panel)
column5: took a chip out of the top of my hood near the windshield
column6: and put swirl marks on the hood when they washed the car after fixing the paint blemishes.

column1: Took the car back in last week and they claimed to have fixed the problem - evidently
column2: the firewall on the car is a polymer piece glued to the metal frame - they stated that this wasn't bonded correctly
column3: causing the firewall to flex and make the noise. (In the process of doing the repair
column4: they used a jack to hold the polymer up to the metal
column5: knowing they were mangling the strut-tower brace - ordered me a new one). Got the call that the car was fixed late last week. Didn't drive it much this weekend since we were driving the wife's new Envoy
column6: but
column7: on Monday on the way to work
column8: the same clunking noise on turns was evident. Also
column9: twice this week the dash has gone crazy (once it told me I needed gas immediately when I had half a tank
column10: the next time it told me the engine was hot
column11: right after starting the car after it sitting for 4 hours).

column1: I have been speaking with GM Executive Relations and the dealership's VP of Service on an almost daily basis since the beginning of week 2 in the shop. My own personal suspicion is that the dealership never did the PDI on the car
column2: and never removed the styrofoam blocks on the front suspension
column3: or the spring spacers on the rear (I had asked them not to detail the car
column4: as I clayed and Zaino'd it extensively - however found out after driving it for nearly a week that the tire pressure was still at 60 psi it was shipped from Oz - explained the large amounts of rubber on the rims). Driving around for 800+ miles with the suspension packing materials may have hosed the suspension. Again
column5: that's just my suspicion (other GTO owners have told me that they had the styrofoam noise and that this was this exact issue - one buyer had to return his car after only 3 mile due to the control arms getting bent due to this issue). The ride quality was noticeably better when I picked it up after the two weeks...

column1: I have 1150 miles on the car and it probably needs to be in the shop 10 more days before either GM throws in the towel
column2: or I have to file lemon law. Of course
column3: the '04's are dwindling
column4: and
column5: especially since there are only 600 Cosmos Purple cars made
column6: half auto and half stick
column7: the likelihood of me getting an exact replacement decreases on a daily basis...

column1: I'm supposed to meet with the service VP and the Pontiac Zone rep at the dealership tomorrow to take them for a test-drive and hear the noise. We'll see how they decide to proceed. Sometimes I think the service VP would like to just do what I want and get me a new car
column2: but GM seems commited to play this one out ""by the rules"" - nevermind the fact that I and my wife have been pretty loyal GM customers over the years.
2004 2:38AM	stickguy	I would fight for a replacement. Even if they somehow manage to fix the initial problems
column3: it sounds like they have messed up enough other things that it will never be the same. It's not hard to see leaks developing
column4: never mind the body damage.

column1: Regarding premium gas... this is a result of the continuing horsepower wars
column2: and the need for higher-compression engines to get more HP. I don't know about other states
column3: but here in the Midwest
column4: premium gas has a 15-20 cent premium over regular (tends to be higher at the bigger-name stations like Amoco
column5: Mobil
column6: and Shell
column7: tends to be less at the Clark and Citgo stations). How much more it costs depends on your MPG and how many miles per year you drive. Let's assume 20 mpg and 15k/year. That's 750 gallons of gas burned each year. At a 15c premium
column8: that's $112.50 per year. Less than $10/mo. For me personally
column9: that's not a big deal and it's not going to stop me from picking the vehicle/engine that I'd like.

column2: most people will waste more than that in not doing their research/getting a good deal on the vehicle they buy
column3: or in obtaining the best finance rate they can (i.e. getting approved by a local bank or credit union before walking into the dealership). Not to mention the issues of maintenance (changing a fuel filter
column4: cleaning injectors
column5: keeping tire pressure accurate
column6: changing plugs and wires when it's time)
column7: which may cost that much in gas (less optimal mileage) in a year's time. And then there's folks like a former co-worker of mine
column8: who used to frequently keep pushing the gas pedal down about 1/4 then lifting off it as we rolled down the freeway
column9: instead of using the cruise or just holding his foot on the pedal and maintaining speed...

column10: a clutch while it was all apart

column12: until the thermostat decided to stick open
column13: and I made a feeble attempt to replace
column14: which didn't go at all well as the pot-metal threads stripped out of the water outlet. Since it was winter

column17: and took 6 months to get the check. By that time I was used to it

column1: To everyone else here: We should keep Gee and Anony in our thoughts and prayers that his body will not reject the new organ. column2: though fortunately
column3: most fully recovered through the use of anti-rejection drugs."

2004 9:27PM	andre1969	"because I knew too many people
column3: first-hand
column4: who had problems with them. Back in the late 80's
column5: a friend of mine didn't actually have a car of his own
column6: but his family had a bunch of cars
column7: and he'd just drive whichever one was available. Usually it was a '72 Dart or an '83 Stanza. Well
column8: that Stanza was junk by the fall of '88
column9: when they drove it
column10: wheezing and smoking
column11: to the Ford dealership and traded on a brand-new '89 Escort LX 2-door hatchback. They got $1800 in trade on it
column12: but I think the dealer just did that to make them feel good
column13: as they paid about $9
column14: 000 for that Escort!

column1: I also knew a few people who had later-gen Stanzas
column2: the Maxima-based one. Seems like those things liked to break timing chains
column3: which would kill the engine because it was an interference design. The 3.0 Nissan used in the Maxima seemed prone to doing that
column4: as well back then.

column1: My Mom & stepdad had a '91 Stanza
column2: and its tranny started to crap around the 90000 mile mark. In early 1998 they decided to start getting rid of some of their cars
column3: so they offered to either give me their '86 Monte
column4: which had about 179
column5: 000 miles on it
column6: or sell me the Stanza. Well
column7: the Stanza was getting to the point that it needed a tuneup
column8: exhaust work
column9: and tranny work
column10: while the Monte felt like it was good for another 100
column11: 000 miles or so
column12: so I took the Monte!

column1: Now that Stanza was able to nurse that tranny to around 110-120
column2: 000 miles
column3: when they sold it. So I don't know exactly what was wrong with it. Anyway
column4: personally I thought that Stanza was crap
column5: but they liked it enough to buy a '99 Altima
column6: one of those funky ""origami"" styled ones.

column1: It's tranny took a dump at 35
column2: 000 miles. That didn't leave me with a good feeling for Nissan quality. However
column3: Nissan did replace it under warranty
column4: and I don't think the car gave them any more fits until around the 80-90
column5: 000 mile mark
column6: when it left them stranded. Twice. Turns out it was just the battery
column7: something I don't fully understand. I can see a battery failing to start a car
column8: but I've actually pulled the battery out of my Dart while it was running
column9: and as long as the positive cable didn't touch anything
column10: it would run just fine. But I guess newer cars can't do that!

column2: they still have that '99 Altima
column3: and it now has over 150
column4: 000 miles on it
column5: so in the long run
column6: it's proving to be a good car for them.

column1: The last negative Nissan experience I've had was early in the year. A friend of mine has a 2001.5 Passat
column2: that was giving him no end of trouble
column3: and he had an '03 Sentra as a loaner. Now that thing was a wretched little car IMO
column4: but it was also a rental
column5: so I guess you can't blame it all on the car! He also had an '03 Intrepid SE for a few weeks
column6: and one day we compared it to my '00 base model and played a little game of ""Find The Cost Cutting"". Sadly
column7: it wasn't a very hard game to play!

column1: I really like the current-gen Altima
column2: though. And since the '05 restyle
column3: I like it even better. I took an '02 out for a test drive back around March of '02
column4: and really liked it. Honestly
column5: if I weren't so upside-down on my Intrepid at the time
column6: I think I might've actually bought it! It was a 2.5 model
column7: and I think it was the S. It had air conditioning...is that what differentiates the S from the most basic model? It was also a really nice shade of green
column8: that I really liked. Kind of a cross between olive green and a silvery-green. They also had a similar green at the time
column9: that had a bit of a bluish hue to it.

column1: I could've gotten that sucker for invoice at the time
column2: but I was also about $4800 upside down on the Intrepid. They would've been more than happy to roll that into the new loan for me
column3: but I wasn't ready to pay $480 a month for an Altima!"

column1: I think I am becoming obsessive about buying a new car. The car magazines

column5: I know that I really do not NEED a new car and that buying a new car is a very poor way to manage one's finances. What I really do not like is that I sometimes have a hard time getting the idea of buying a new car out of my head. I would much prefer to think about more constructive or creative things. Sometimes the options
column6: colors
column7: comparisons
column8: rating
column9: reviews
column10: specs
column11: and pricing run around in my head out of control.

column1: Deep down I know that buying a new car will only bring momentary happiness and possibly deep disappointment if the new car does not live up to expectations.

column2: gets great gas mileage

column5: a motorcycle

column2: 2004 3:38AM	wildrice	"I agree that the time of year may have something to do with my new car obsession. Since the bicycling season is winding down
column3: I have fewer outdoor activities to keep me busy. Instead of going to the bike shop to obsess over new bikes or pedals
column4: I am stuck at home to read car magazines and watch TV. It is not so easy avoiding car ads
column5: by the way. Car ads are in nearly every section of the newspaper and fill any guy-type magazine. Not to mention saturation car ads on TV. I used to read a free outdoor magazine until it got taken over by SUV ads. Apparently hikers
column6: mountain bikers
column7: and kayakers are favorite targets of SUV makers.

column1: I often get the feeling that society is programming me to buy new cars. Being obsessed with cars is the ""norm"" and is encouraged. I have taken steps. I gathered up all of my car magazines and brochures and put them in a less convenient place. I changed my Windows wall paper from car photos to bike photos. I put the car web sites in one favorites folder and tucked it away in sub folders.
Part of the problem is that I own a '97 Civic EX. At 40
column2: 000 miles it is just barely broken in and will no doubt last 200
column3: 000 miles. Since I drive it 5
column4: 000 miles a year
column5: I could end up driving it 40 years. The problem with Hondas is that you get tired of them long before they conk out on you. Not to mention seeing thousands of identical ones on the road. That's why the tuner craze is a good thing. Tuners cherish their present cars instead of wanting to buy a new car. Tuners make their cars more individual. Tuners wring out the best performance from what they have instead of just checking the bigger engine option when buying a new car.

column1: My Civic EX is lightly modified
column2: which has convinced me to hold onto the car longer. I also agree with someone's suggestion of keeping the car cleaned
column3: washed
column4: and waxed. I have less of an urge to buy a new car when the old one looks good."

column3: we will have cheap oil. But this will not always be the case. Very soon
column4: we will be past the peak and in the era of ever diminishing supply. Also
column5: countries such as China
column6: now require large oil imports. The TV show ""West Wing"" touched on the subject
column7: but did a poor job of stressing the urgency or the global economic implications.

column1: It will result in out of control inflation as the costs of mechanized agriculture
column2: manufacturing
column3: transport
column4: and plastics (petrochemicals) goes up and up. Not to mention wars over the diminishing reserves. Whole parts of the USA will be affected
column5: as home heating oil becomes unaffordable. Pollution will become severe as we are forced to burn more coal.

column2: it makes little sense to buy into the automotive industry when cars will become obsolete. Hybrids are not the complete answer either as it still takes massive amounts of energy to produce a car
column3: whether hybrid or conventional.

column1: My solution is bicycles and scooters. I commute by bicycle 3/4 of the year and ride a scooter (60-70 mpg) the rest of the year. Each day I ride my bicycle instead of drive a car
column2: I save one gallon of gas. It adds up. Imagine burning one gallon of gas in an open field. That is a lot of heat
column3: smoke
column4: stink
column5: and waste."

column2: 2004 2:49PM	wildrice	"I think we desire new cars in the mistaken belief that owning a new car will bring us happiness. I think we all know that the new car ""honeymoon"" period is very brief either due to buyer's regret
column3: mechanical problems
column4: ownership costs
column5: or boredom. I think it's part of human nature to want what we don't have and to be dissatisfied with what we don't have.

column1: If one buys a shiny new car
column2: how long will it be until we get tired of it and want to move on to the next new thing. The automotive industry plays on this
column3: spending more money luring us with more power and sexier designs
column4: instead of more fuel efficiency or practicality.

column2: cars create economic woes: steep depreciation
column3: gasoline costs
column4: insurance
column5: repairs
column6: up keep. There are many
column7: many hidden costs.

column1: I think we want to buy new cars for sometimes illogical reasons of convenience. I am amazed at how many people drive to the local bicycle park
with their bikes loaded into their huge SUV's. I seem to be one of the few who rides his bike there. For awhile
column2: I even considered buying an SUV to carry my bike on out of state trips. Fortunately I realized that a bike rack on the trunk of my Honda Civic worked out just fine (35 mpg on the highway).

column1: I think people can be happy without a car. I was very happy in college when I was carless and poor. Now college kids consider a car to be their birth right. I live near a private University. It's amazing what the rich college students drive: Lexus SUV's
column2: BMW's
column3: sports cars
column4: etc.

column1: I know it would be hard to become carless again
column2: but I am trying to be car light. I try to put more miles on my bicycle than my car."

column3: you are obsessed with buying a car. Now
column4: only a week later
column5: Youa re lecturing us on why we should drop our cars and move to the bicycle.

column1: Your posts are being to sound more like leftist lectures."

column2: 2004 5:22PM	wildrice	"Yes
column3: I admit to having new car buying addiction. This is despite being a bicycle advocate. I had to first admit that I had a problem. The worst thing was having my thoughts preoccupied with researching new cars. I took steps to alleviate the addiction. I had to limit my exposure to car magazines
column4: brochures
column5: and show rooms. Avoiding car ads is more difficult. For example
column6: the Nissan Xterra campaign targets bike riders and outdoors people
column7: like myself.

column1: It is healthier to obsess about your children
column2: health
column3: diet
column4: or exercise than it is to obsess about new cars.

column1: I realized on my 30 mile bike ride today that one of the reasons we like new cars is the basic instinct to return to the womb. Think about it: the temperature controlled environment
column2: heated seats
column3: placenta-like seat cushions
column4: fetal driving position
column5: sound insulation
column6: latte in the cup holder
column7: and enclosed cabin.

column1: The car stereo pumping out familar tunes is just the desire to hear the maternal heart beat.
It is time for us to grow up and break free of our infantile desires!"

2004 10:49PM	wildrice	"There have been some recent items in the news pertaining to car buying. In fact
column3: they are good arguments NOT to buy a new car.

column1: One article said that 2004 had a record number of car recalls. The excuse is the increasing complexity of cars. But it is a worrisome trend. Car makers are obviously in a rush to get new models and fancy gizmos to market without adequate research or testing. We
column2: the consumers
column3: are doing the testing.

column1: The second article was about how Arab oil experts are coming to Texas to find out how to extract the harder to obtain reserves in older oil fields. USA oil production peaked in the early 70's and the former oil gushers had to be pumped and later infused with water. Our geologists had to develope new means of extracting the remaining oil in the fields. Apparently
column2: some of the Arab nations are interested in these techniques. This is a strong signal that mideast oil production will soon be in steady decline (look up Hubbert's Peak). This will spell the end of the petroleum age and the automotive age as we know it.

column1: A third article predicts the real estate bubble to burst. In some areas of the country
column2: houses are way over valued. Also the demographic demand for new houses will be in decline as baby boomers down size and there are fewer new families. Car buying is already a losing proposition due to depreciation. Soon
column3: owning a house could be a losing proposition too.

column1: A fourth article states that the dollar is in steady decline compared to the Euro
column2: Pound
column3: and Yen. The White house likes this
column4: as it favors US exports. But it will also make import cars more expensive. According to Greenspan
column5: if other nations suddenly lose interest in buying devaluing US dollars (which could come with a crash)
column6: we could be headed into major economic problems."

column2: 2004 11:01PM	driftracer	"""a record number of car recalls""

column1: It's not because cars are more complex
column2: or they have more problems
column3: or they fail in droves
column4: it's because the vehicle manufacturers want to cover their corporate butts by doing preventive maintenance against possible law suits
column5: especially class actions.

column2: in the court's eyes
column3: the manufacturer is released from liability in a major way
column4: or at least their liability had been drastically reduced."

column3: rent a car!""

column2: car usage and ownership wasn't taken away

column2: and the car stayed at my sister's house...the other thing was that people may vandalize a dirty car that sits for days on end if they think its abandoned...that scenario got my mom concerned to the point where she didn't want the car at the retirement home

column3: dad had alzheimers and didn't care about a car...he passed July 2003. My oldest brother essentially stole the car

column1: Nobody can screw you like family can screw you..."

column2: 2004 7:38AM	nippononly	"just for some Friday night fun
column3: I visited a couple of dealers tonight. Thinking of maybe just possibly replacing my 4Runner with something much more modern next year
column4: wanted to see what my options were and wanted to try a range of vehicles.

column2: wanted to drive one of the new Outbacks. Guess what? 100 automatics in stock
column3: not one manual. So I skipped the drive
column4: but it is rated 23/28 for mileage and PZEV for emissions
column5: acceptable I guess. The guy says he gets manuals all the time and will call me. Lots of standard features for a good price. Good space in the back with the seats down
column6: and good space if you have to sit in the back seat. No separate pop-up glass in the hatchback though. Still has those Subaru frameless windows that I was never that fond of with my last Subie.

column1: Then I was off to check out the new Tacoma in person. V-6 4X4s can be had in stick shift (6 speed no less)
column2: and are even on dealer lots
column3: a pleasant surprise. The mileage rating is atrocious: 16/20. That is no better than my 15-year-old truck's real world mileage (gets 17 most of the time
column4: 20 on highway trips). The power is good
column5: but this may be more than I need; these days I mainly use it for camping and skiing
column6: and the days of major offroading are decreasing. The extended cab now has rear-opening half doors for the jump seats in back
column7: and the design is such that they rattle incessantly. The clutch is so light you can't tell where it is engaging at all
column8: and the engine is so smog-strangled that the engine revs take about a year to fall between each gear
column9: meaning until you get used to it you lurch into every gear.

column1: Last stop was the intermediate between those two: Jeep Liberty. Drove it and loved it. Great vehicle
column2: price is good (several thousand cheaper than the Tacoma)
column3: TINY turning radius
column4: separate pop-open hatch glass (can you tell I like that?!)
column5: back seat is tight but that might be OK. Then came the downers: got back to the dealership only to be informed by the sales manager (the salesman was clueless) that 6-speed manuals
column6: while supposedly available
column7: are not being delivered at all by Jeep
column8: and while he could take an order from me
column9: he could not guarantee a delivery date nor would there be one I could test drive to be sure I liked the manual. They tried to tell me what i really wanted was the automatic. Such an annoying trait in salespeople
column10: and the automatic is nothing special in the slightest. So that is on hold
column11: they too have my number. Then I get home to discover on the evening news that more than half a million Dakotas and Durangos are being recalled for defective ball joints
column12: and that more than a dozen have had wheels fall right off
column13: and this gives me grave doubts that I would want a product from the related Jeep company right now anyway...not to mention that if I had decided on the Tacoma
column14: I was aiming to test it again back to back with the Dakota
column15: which is substantially cheaper
column16: but I don't think I will do that now.

column1: Between the two I preferred the Liberty anyway
column2: still reserving judgment on the Outback though. Why oh why is it that manufacturers make such a big deal out of having a standard manual for a model
column3: then they don't actually BUILD any? That Jeep sales manager said that in three years of selling the Liberty
column4: he had seen no more than a half dozen stick shifts. Of course
column5: that was at the point when he was trying to tell me that what I really wanted was an automatic
column6: so maybe he was making it up.

column1: Back to the drawing boards...gotta keep my membership current! :-P"

column2: 2004 7:44AM	jlawrence01	"There are three or four issues with accounting for business mileage.

column1: 1) The best method (for tax reporting) is if you are reimbursed for business mileage
column2: preferably at the federal rate. This is NOT considered INCOME.

column1: 2) If the company provides you a car (not the case here)
column2: the driver is responsible for tracking the business mileage
column3: commuting mileage
column4: and the personal mileage. You report that to the employer and the personal and commuting mileage is added to your W-2 (line 7) income.

column1: 3) What you have here is a non-accountable plan which is a *royal* PITA. All funds provided by the company is considered income and will show up on your W-2. You have to do the mileage tracking and track your expenses. You have two options. First
column2: you can declare the car expenses and allocate them between personal and business use. That is also a pain. The better option is to track the mileage and use the government rate. Either way
column3: it is a rip because you have to get over the 2% threshhold.

column1: If you use the mileage option
column2: you get the same federal rate whether you are driving a Geo Metro or a Rolls Royce.
I would be looking for the most reliable and cheap beater."

column2: 2005 4:42PM	jlawrence01	"You have to be very careful when planning a move that you know about ALL of the taxes.
Ohio and Missouri have very similar STATE income taxes. However
column3: in Ohio
column4: each city levies a city income tax on income earned IN the city AND income on its residents. So if you live in Cleveland and live in a suburb
column5: you pay local taxes to **BOTH** cities. If you don't know this
column6: you may be paying as much as an additional 4% without factirong that into your new salary.

column1: Some states levy taxes on personal property. On some
column2: it it actually a percentage of the value of the vehicle. For me
column3: that's cool as I drive beaters BUT if you are a car collector
column4: you'll be shelling out a lot more.

column1: Ditto on property taxes. I have seen $2000 differences between identically priced $150k houses that are actually located within ONE mile of each other.

column4: and nothing but the facts (g)."

column2: etc.
column3: IIRC. Our governor's race is in November
column4: and the issue that will shape the race is to finish abolishing VA's car tax. It was designed to be phased out completely (first $20K of a car's value IIRC) by a sliding scale over a few years
column5: but it stopped at 70% in the early 00's due to budget deficit. Now the state seems to be generating more revenue than predicted (increased property taxes no doubt!)
column6: so the likely republican candidate wants to abolish it completely. Democratic governor says not yet
column7: etc. Should be interesting to follow as the election gets closer.

column1: Since I purchased three new GM cars in the last two years
column2: the quick domestic car depreciation curse should help me have no car tax if that initiative does continue forward! LOL!

column1: I am fortunate to own a second home in Delaware
column2: which is the home of tax-free shopping. Guess where I do most of my shopping? And their property tax rates are just cheap! Less than one-forth of my VA real estate tax. But they make that up with each real estate transaction--closing costs (tax stamps
column3: etc.) are outrageous."

column2: 2005 11:25PM	fintail	"I didn't know where to put this
column3: so I guess I'll put it on a popular thread. I found this elsewhere online:

column1: Remote Car Keys.......... Very Interesting Information
Handy bit of trivia to know.
For those of you who have a car that can be unlocked by that remote button on your key ring: If you lock your keys in the car and the spare keys are home
column2: and you don't have ""OnStar
column3: here's your answer to the problem!

column1: If some one has access to the spare remote at your home
column2: call them on your cell phone (or borrow one from someone if the cell phone is locked in the car too!)

column1: Hold your (or anyone's) cell phone about a foot from your car door and have the other person at your home press the unlock button
column2: holding it near the phone on their end.

column1: Saves someone from having to drive your keys to you. Distance is no object. You could be hundreds of miles away
column2: and if you can reach someone who has the other ""remote"" for your car
column3: you can unlockthe doors (or the trunk
column4: or have the ""horn"" signal go off
column5: or whatever!)

column1: (Editor's Note * It works fine! We tried it out and it unlocked our car over a cell phone!) Distance doesn't seem to be a factor."

2005 2:25PM	ddelise	"Ok -

column1: Here's the deal. My current lease has 2 payments remaining at $410 each.

I started my shopping this month (a Vibe or a Maxx) and let the dealers know up front I was a couple of months out to making my final decision. And they were cool with that. I also let them know I am eligible for GM Supplier pricing
column2: and have GM Card Earnings. Unfortunately the two programs are no longer allowed together
column3: so I asked if they would honor the Supplier price to allow me to use my earnings. Each said Yes.

column2: and then asked the dealer to see what models qualify for the additional $1000 March Madness cash. Just curious of course...

column1: She came back to me with 2 LS models and 6 LT models that qualify. She then put me on the phone with the finance manager to discuss a lease cost. All numbers were the same as Car_Man has indicated to me in the Lease Questions forum
column2: and then they dropped the bomb that the LS has $2500 lease cash and the LT $2000 lease cash (including the March Madness money). This is $1000 and $500 more lease cash respectively than Car_Man or GM sites indicate. Clearly they are passing along every incentive to try and get me to make a deal.

column1: My final question was then about the dealer fee of $500 (yes
column2: that much in Florida). I said with the Supplier Program the fee is waived. They came back and said that they are making $30 on the sale of the car at the Supplier Price and not marking up the finance rate at all and passing along every rebate to me
column3: so there is no more room for them. But they then said it is the end of the month (and quarter I suspect)
column4: so they will ask the General Manager.

column1: Two hours later I get a phone call. They said they must show the $500 fee in the deal on the contract
column2: but will then cut me a check for $500 - so in a sense the fee is $0.

column1: Bottom line is I can lease the Maxx LS for about $175 and the LT for about $205. Both include tax
column2: no cap cost
column3: and startups (first payment
column4: tax
column5: tag) due at signing.

column1: Should I pull the trigger and eat the remaining payments on my car?
Should I hold out until my lease is over and see what deals are out there then?
And I will say this dealer is awesome to deal with - totally upfront with price
column2: rebates
column3: financing
column4: etc. They are motivated to sell a Maxx!

column1: It's a '76 Pontiac Grand LeMans. The Grand LeMans used the Grand Prix dashboard (as did the Can Am and the '73-75 Grand Am)
column2: where the base LeMans used a different dash layout. I didn't notice it at first
column3: until Lemko said ""1977 LeMans""
column4: but the while it was advertised as a '76
column5: it does appear to be wearing the '77 Grand LeMans grille. I'll have to ask the owner about that. I've been looking at pics of these cars online
column6: and noticed that a few of them have the wrong-year grille on them. The LeMans and Grand LeMans had different grilles
column7: and they changed them both from '76-77
column8: but they're all swappable. So I'm wondering if some previous owner just swapped in a grille that he liked better? Or maybe one of the sections got broken
column9: and he could only find a '77 in the junkyard
column10: so he took both pieces to make them match? I had to do something similar when I had my '82 Cutlass Supreme. One day I was showing off
column11: and showing my friends how the grille inserts were on hinges
column12: and folded inward to protect them in the event of an accident. Well
column13: lo and behold
column14: the danged thing broke off the moment I touched it! Naturally my friends laughed at it! :blush: That'll be the last time I brag about a GM product!!

column2: I went to a junkyard
column3: and the only Cutlass that would serve as a donor was an '82 Brougham
column4: which had a different grille from the base Cutlass. So I had to buy both pieces to make it fit. And I never showed off that little ""feature"" again
column5: for fear I'd break it again! BTW
column6: my '79 Newport and '79 NYer grilles would do the same thing. Hinged on the top
column7: they'd give a couple inches in light impacts. I never showed them off though
