column2: 2005 1:09AM	andre1969	"I would've addressed it earlier
column3: but your message popped in while I was typing that long one. I've heard Lemko mention a few times that he hates the '73-77 GM intermediates. He could probably explain it better
column4: but I think it's mainly because he likes the '68-72 intermediates so much better. And to be fair
column5: the '68-72's were a great style
column6: and could be had with some powerful engines.

column1: The 1973 intermediates did away with all hardtops and convertibles
column2: leaving only 2- and 4-door pillared models
column3: along with wagons
column4: although they all had frameless door windows
column5: just like a Subaru! GM did this in reaction to proposed federal guidelines that regulated rollover protection
column6: and would have most likely made it too expensive to make a hardtop or convertible to comply. In a rare move of GM moving too fast for once
column7: they came out with these ""Colonade"" pillared hardtops
column8: as they were called
column9: in anticipation of these new regs
column10: and the regs never materialized!

column2: it was destined to happen anyway. 4-door hardtops were never popular in the compact and intermediate lineups
column3: although they were a mainstay for larger cars
column4: especially luxury models like the Electra
column6: DeVille
column7: New Yorker
column8: etc. AFAIK Chrysler never offered a midsize 4-door hardtop
column9: unless you want to count the shrunken standard Dodges and Plymouths around '62-64. Ford offered a Torino 4-door hardtop around 70-71
column10: but it was a slow seller. As for 2-door hardtops
column11: they started to fall by the wayside as it became evident in the 70's that ""personal luxury"" and pimpy was the in-thang
column12: and as opera windows and thickly-padded roofs came into vogue
column13: and air conditioning was installed on the majority of cars
column14: nobody cared if the rear windows rolled down or not.

column1: I have a history book that calls the '73-77 GM intermediates ""The last all-new designs in the traditional GM way of building cars...big on the outside
column2: small on the inside
column3: heavy
column4: posh
column5: and thirsty""! These monsters were kind of the antithesis of the trim
column6: sporty '68-72 models. If it's any consolation though
column7: the LeMans I'm getting is still smaller than its Ford or Mopar counterparts of the era! Its wheelbase is 112""
column8: and overall length is ""only"" 208"" And I think it's actually a touch UNDER 4000 lb! :shades:"

column2: 2005 1:49PM	lemko	...was that the '73-77 intermediates initially switched to dual from quad headlights. It makes the cars look cheap.
2005 1:58PM	andre1969	"yeah
column3: I didn't like that either. Back when I was a little kid
column4: I used to equate quad headlights as a cue that a car was upscale from a car with single headlights. Interestingly
column5: GM had to push to get government approval to start using rectangular headlights on their cars. They first showed up in '75 on some Caddy/Olds/Buick models
column6: but didn't show up until '76 on the GM intermediates.

column1: One of GM's arguments for rectangular headlights was that they would be smaller than round headlights
column2: and therefore would allow for a lower hoodline that would improve visibility and aerodynamics a bit. So what do they do
column3: then? They STACKED these rectangular headlights vertically on some cars
column4: like the Chevelle
column5: Monte Carlo
column6: and Buick Century. So much for the lowered hoodline
column7: huh?

column2: back then
column3: so went GM
column4: so went the rest of the auto industry
column5: so Ford started stacking the headlights on the LTD-II replacement for the Torino in '77
column6: and Chrysler started stacking the headlights on the midsized Coronet/Monaco that year
column7: too. The Cordoba followed suit in '78
column8: IIRC.

column1: My Mom had a '75 LeMans when I was a kid
column2: and the single headlights were one thing I didn't like on that car. I thought that the '76
column3: with its rectangular quad headlights was a massive improvement
column4: and it also worked better with the massive 5 mph bumper."

column2: 2005 3:33PM	michaellno	"I owned a Sunbird coupe .. it was a 1979 model year that I bought in the spring of 1982 for $3700. It only had 11
column3: 000 miles on it; the previous owners were elderly and didn't drive the car too much. 2.5L ""Iron Duke"" 4-banger with a 4 speed manual transmission. Beige with beige interior.

column1: Drove it until the summer of '85 .. that car gave me no end of problems. I bought it when I was still in HS in CA
column2: but a year later I moved to PHX to attend college. It hated the hot weather! I had all sorts of problems with it not wanting to start when the weather was warm ... I used my first credit card (Sears
column3: natch) to rack up several hundred dollars in repair bills trying to figure out what was wrong.

column1: Was involved in two accidents with that car ... the first one wasn't my fault -- a lady tried to make a left turn in front of me. Unfortunately
column2: when the car was repaired
column3: the shop didn't fix all the problems with it -- they never noticed the two broken motor mounts
column4: which ultimately caused problems with the transmission. I couldn't get it into reverse.

column1: Was on my way to the transmission shop when accident #2 occurred. The car in front of me slowed down to turn right onto a side street. I was in the process of changing lanes and taken that exact moment to look over my left shoulder to see if the lane next to me was clear. It was
column2: but I didn't get over in time and rear-ended the car. Insurance totalled it and I got a $2000 check -- this was about 3-4 months before I was scheduled to graduate.
not a bad little car. No A/C
column3: so I bought two sheepskin seat covers and used the 2/55 method of keeping cool. I had already installed an aftermarket sunroof while I lived in CA
column4: so that came in handy as well.

column2: one other thing is interesting. It went through tires pretty quickly. When I moved to AZ from CA
column3: I stopped in Yuma
column4: AZ to spend some time with relatives and noticed that the front tires were pretty worn .. ended up buying 2 new Firestones.

column2: I was coming back to AZ after a holiday in CA. Was doing 70-75 on I-10 just outside of PHX when the tread on the right rear tire separated from the belts .. made the most God-awful noise. In fact
column3: the rubber that was still attached to the tire actually made a dent in the rear rocker panel! Scared the heck out of my passengers -- a classmate
column4: my sister and her best friend. Had to drive on the worn out tire for 5 or 6 miles to get to the next town and get new tires installed again.

column2: memories....."

column2: 2005 2:19PM	robr2	"Andre - watch out for some of the tips being passed on. The idea of getting of the flight in the connecting city can create havoc for the airline and TSA. Since 9/11
column3: the flight attendants have to count the passengers on the plane before takeoff and comapre it to the manifest. If their manifest shows you are missing
column4: it throws up all sorts of warning sirens and may warrant a visit from the TSA. Also
column5: before 9/11 airlines used to do the same thing but it was to allow them to charge you the fare for the flight you took
column6: not the flight you booked. It's all on the back of the ticket.

column1: As for not using the return flight
column2: the same thing applies. The airline can charge you for what you booked
column3: not what you took.

column2: 2005 2:30AM	akangl	"Nah
column3: not this time. Ok
column4: here's the numbers:

column1: The truck with the 4 of us in it (and no
column2: we aren't THAT heavy
column3: lol)
column4: a full tank of gas
column5: and the hitch in the receiver weighs in at a WHOPPING 6105 lbs according to the scales. Now the SE that I had weighed in at 5900 lbs on the same scales and I foolishly assumed the LE would be similar in weight.

column2: now the GVWR of the truck is 6499 lbs
column3: so 6499-6105= 394 lbs for payload and tongue weight. The DRY tongue weight of the travel trailer that we bought is 494 lbs (see the problem yet??). The trailer has a dry weight of 4476 and a GVWR of 6200 lbs.

column1: The travel trailer is an ultra light made for 1/2 ton trucks
column2: however
column3: the Titan has a lower GVWR than any other 1/2 ton on the market.

column1: The Titan has a GCWR (gross combined) of 14800 lbs
column2: so even fully loaded we are ok there. Its the GVWR that's kicking our butts. I guess we will either not tow the trailer with the Titan (hence not use it at all) or we will run overloaded (at least 500 lbs over the GVWR when all said and done).
I'm really not rationalizing THIS time
column3: we really do have a major problem here."

column2: 2005 6:25PM	andre1969	"well
column3: now that I'm awake (sort of)
column4: I figure I'd give y'all a few details about my trip and the car. The trip out was pretty uneventful
column5: perfect weather. Took just under 8 hours to get out there. It was about 520 miles
column6: total

column2: the car didn't look quite as good in person as it did in the pictures (they rarely do)
column3: but I didn't see anything that scared me away. There's a little rust starting at the lower edge of the landau roof at the C-pillar
column4: which was a common area
column5: but it's minor enough that if I take care of it quickly
column6: it shouldn't be a major deal. There were also a few dings and scratches here and there
column7: but nothing too major. And you can see flaws in the paint if you get close to it
column8: like areas where it was put on a bit too thick
column9: got a bit of orange peel
column10: and maybe a little bubble here and there. Inside the only real flaws were a torn driver's seat
column11: and the panel on the dash between the windshield and the padded part was a bit warped
column12: and wouldn't fasten down. Oh
column13: and the clock doesn't work.

column2: I was actually impressed by the way this sucker handled! I was expecting something much more floaty and boat-like. And I thought looking out over that looooong hood would be intimidating. Now I've had cars that are much bigger than this thing (at 208"" it's actually kinda tiny compared to some of the monsters I've had)
column3: but from the outside this thing looks like it's all hood! The front-end slopes downward though
column4: as do the blades on the tops of fenders. In a strange way though
column5: it felt a bit like being behind the wheel of ""The Car"" (that classic 1977 movie about Satan's hotrod). And the thick rear roof quarters with their little opera windows don't create as much of a blind spot as one might think. The C-pillars extend pretty far back
column6: though
column7: and at a quick glance in the mirror
column8: they make me think something's cruising in my blind spot. The tailfins of my '57 DeSoto do that too
column9: to a certain degree. I guess it's just that there's part of my car in a place that I'm not used to seeing in my mirror!

column1: The biggest handicap is probably the steering
column2: which while responsive
column3: is typical 70's car in its lack of feedback. It'll point you where you want to go with ease
column4: but just doesn't give you any road feel while doing it. Now I don't know how a Pontiac 350-2bbl is supposed to perform in a car like this
column5: but this one wasn't bad. I'm sure the shift kit in the tranny helped somewhat. It can be a bit of a shock though
column6: when a car like this is so ready to downshift to 2nd at 70 mph
column7: though! It also has dual exhaust
column8: so that might have helped a bit.

column1: Let's not talk about fuel economy
column2: though. I figure around 15 mpg
column3: on the highway. with 89 octane. We were doing 70-80 most of the way though
column4: so that might've had something to do with it! I wonder if I tried some of those annoying hypermiler techniques
column5: maybe I could get it up to over 20? I think the Intrepid was doing about 25 mpg on this trip.

column2: overall
column3: no leaks
column4: no nasty noises
column5: except for a loose bumper guard and A-pillar trim the seller pointed out to me. Surprisingly
column6: this car didn't even squeak or rattle. I guess GM actually DID build one or two good ones back then! And this sucker is comfortable
column7: too. As low slung as the car is
column8: I'm surprised at how high up the seating position was
column9: although part of that may be because of the power seat. It's pretty well-padded
column10: and although todays' seats give you much better contouring to keep your butt planted in sharp cornering
column11: it still seems to me that
column12: for the time period at least
column13: GM actually DID put some effort into their cars. Well
column14: some of them at least!

column1: Kyfdx met me at the seller's place of business
column2: where I picked up the car. And for someone who showed up in a BMW 3-series and normally drives a CR-V
column3: he reacted well to my little piece of 70's nostalgia! :shades: We ate at a nearby Steak & Shake. Nice place
column4: good food. Too bad they don't have those out here. Nice meeting ya
column5: Walt! If you're ever planning on coming out my way
column6: give me a shout! And if I'm ever back that way
column7: I'll do the same!"

column2: 2005 1:57PM	jjtj	"I don't think it's the frame that you need to be most worried about. If you make sure you have a ""D"" or ""E"" load rated tire
column3: that will take care of alot of it. I'd be more worried about the braking system
column4: transmission & suspension. Make sure to service your transmission often. I plow snow with my Silverado & do the fluid/filter swap twice per year. Way more than indicated but it really extends the life. Another thing you could do is to get a set of Timbren suspension boosters for the rear axle. They're thick
column5: rubber springs that mount onto the axle that reduce the ""squat"" of the suspension when you load it with the hitch
column6: etc. I use them on the front suspension of my Silverado to reduce the stress of the 800 LB snowplow cantilevered off the front end. I don't know how much
column7: if any
column8: they increase the GVWR
column9: but they really reduce the amount the front drops when the plow is lifted. Plus they take alot of stress off of the control arms
column10: ball joints
column11: etc. They're easy to install & the front set only cost about $150 delivered. Goto www.timbrens.com.. they explain it in more detail. There's also an application chart to see if they're offered for the Titan."

column3: and Civic EX's since 1996 (I think)... Many dealers list it on the used car spec sheet whether the car has it or not. Our favorite pasttime was going to a used car lot by our grandma's house & trying to determine model years by the numbers molded into the tail light lens. My favorite movie back then (& still) is Smokey & the Bandit. I must have seen it at least 50 times.. not to go off on that tangent
column2: but if you get ""AMC"" on cable

Anyways
column3: they knew some people down around Cincy that collected 240's. I was 15 & my stepdad decided it would be a good first car.. so we drove down

column5: I hesitate to call it BRG but it was ugly whatever the color. It had a 4-speed stick
column6: inline-6 with sidedraft carbs. It had a fake wood steering wheel too. It needed some work but it was a blast to drive. MPG's sucked
column7: but IIRC gas was about .79 a gallon in 1987. They ended up getting a divorce a few years later but the good memories end up pushing out the bad. He used to take me to work with him when I was about 13
column8: I think.. he worked in the oil business & he used to have to check on the wells. They were always at the end of a dirt road that was usually packed with mud. He had a Toyota Land Cruiser (FJ-40)
column9: the kind that looks like a Jeep.. anyways
column10: one day he pulls over & says ""change places with me"". I think it was a 4-spd stick
column11: & I had no idea how to drive a stick. He throws it into 4WD & off we go. It still puts a smile on my face thinking about it. I had that thing sideways through a huge mud pit.. next thing he did was let me drive on the actual paved roads.. it was a small town & I remember rolling past the chief of police.. I was scared s***less but he just waved as we went by. It was a very small town with not much traffic so I guess it was a good place to learn. At least I knew how to work the clutch in the 240Z when I turned 16!"

column2: 2005 8:50AM	boomchek	"True about driving stick. Here's something a fellow salesperson told me that he tells every parent contemplating between buying stick or auto vehicle for their kids.

column1: When you give your daughter or son a car to drive
column2: it is inevitable that sooner or later they will drive it to a party or to a hang out to meet their friends. It is also very likely (even though we all hope it never happens) that where ever they're going there might or will be alcohol there
column3: and as a result there will be drunk people (teens
column4: young adults) at the party. Alcohol and teens don't mix but when they do usually somebody ends up doing stupid things
column5: like borrowing or snatching their friend's car keys and taking their friend's car for a spin. By having a standard tranny car
column6: that situation might not happen because MOST people these days don't know how to drive stick. If they don't know then they can't take off in your kid's car. (It might seem far fetched but I've seen it happen a few times where a vehicle or two was totalled because a friend let their drunk friend borrow their car for a quick spin).

column1: Anyways teaching your son or daughter how to drive stick will give them an advantage in some situations over others who don't know how to do it. Even if she despises driving stick six months from now at least she'll understand the concept
column2: and who knows if she might need to use it in the future?

column2: 2005 4:23PM	michaellno	"I've had 2 vehicles with a 5-speed auto - the '02 Explorer and the wife's '04 VUE V6.

column1: The Explorer tranny wasn't that great
column2: IMO. Constantly hunted between gears. The VUE
column3: OTOH
column4: is a sweetheart. Of course
column5: having a Honda-sourced engine certainly doesn't hurt. When we took the VUE to Santa Fe back in March
column6: I was absolutely blown away by how smooth it was .. I set the cruise to 80 and
column7: even on the steepest grades
column8: it would seemlessly downshift one or two gears to maintain the set speed. The revs would go up to 3500 or so
column9: but it was still very quiet.

column1: The only thing I don't like about the tranny is the selections on the gearshift .. there are only 3:
Drive - allows all 5 gears to be used
Intermediate - only allows gears 1 - 3 to be used

Would love to have some sort of tiptronic like feature available. Friends of ours have an '04 Santa Fe with the 3.5L V6 and a 5-speed auto with the manu-matic. Nice to be able to pick your own gears upon occasion.
The L300 only has a 4-speed auto
column2: which
column3: 95% of the time
column4: is adequate. The only issue I have is when I have it on cruise at 70-75MPH and I encounter a hill
column5: it downshifts to 3rd gear and the revs jump from 2500-2700 to almost 4000. Makes a bit of a ruckus
column6: then it has a hard time upshifting back to 4th when the road levels out. I usually have to hit the ""coast"" button for a moment to get the transmission to go back into 4th gear.

column2: if 5 speeds are good
column3: then 6 and 7 speeds must be better! Ask Ford and MB on that ... do you think that we'll see more cars with 6 and 7 speed automatics
column4: or will CVT's become more prevalent.

column2: 2005 4:33PM	andre1969	"that you see a diminishing rate of return as you add more gears to a transmission? Back when trannies started going from 2-speed to 3-speed units (GM's Hydramatic actually started off as a 4-speed
column3: way back in 1939!)
column4: there was a huge improvement in performance.

column2: in the 80's
column3: when 4-speed overdrive trannies started replacing the 3-speeds
column4: they were a boost mainly to highway economy
column5: but also helped performance all around
column6: as the auto makers could now put shorter axle ratios in the cars to help low-end performance
column7: while overdrive would still knock it down to a lazy highway cruiser.

column1: A 5-speed automatic would certainly benefit cars with smaller engines that really have to rev
column2: and maybe big engines that are pretty weak
column3: but do they really help out that much with engines that are well-balanced to begin with? The main reason that the 5-speed is an improvement over the 4-speed in the Chrysler LX cars is probably because the 4-speed just isn't a well-designed unit to begin with. Not necessarily because it lacks an extra gear.

column1: My Intrepid feels like it could use an extra gear between 3rd and 4th sometimes. Once you go into 4th
column2: it really has no power
column3: but at higher speeds when it downshifts to 3rd
column4: in some situations it just seems like overkill. For example
column5: at 75 mph I'm pulling 2500 rpm in 4th
column6: and around 3750 in 3rd.

column1: Are CVT trannies to the point yet that they can handle the load of bigger engines? In the past
column2: I always thought that was their main weak point
column3: that they just weren't that strong of a design."

column5: ""4DSC"" style Nissan Maxima. I've always loved that body style. This one was black
column6: with the spoiler and alloys and looked beautiful. And it had a ""for sale"" sign in the window! I pulled over and started talking with the owner
column7: an older lady who was out working in her garden. As I looked it over
column8: she told me she had owned it since 1994 and was planning on keeping it but her kids convinced her to get a newer car - after she had spent a ton of money fixing it up. She ended up with an Elantra GT
column9: and I could tell she regretted selling the Max.

column1: This is the mythical ""little old lady"" car. We're talking cream puff
column2: in the wrapper
column3: etc. It's a '91 with 132k miles
column4: and other than the body style it could pass for an '01 with 32k miles. In the last year
column5: she's replaced all the belts and hoses (including the timing belt)
column6: all 6 fuel injectors
column7: the alternator
column8: battery
column9: struts
column10: powerflushed the transmission
column11: had it aligned
column12: recharged the A/C
column13: and replaced all 4 tires with Michelins. It drives beautifully. She always kept it garaged
column14: and parked way out in the parking lot so it wouldn't get any dings or scratches. The only damage it has ever had was a parking lot incident that required a new grille and driver's side headlight
column15: and if she hadn't told me I wouldn't have known. The rest of the paint is original. The interior is immaculate. She had the ENTIRE seating area professionally covered with sheepskins
column16: including the back seat and the head rests
column17: so the seats are perfect. She even had covers over the dashboard and the rear deck where the speakers are installed. Even the stupid automatic seatbelts work perfectly. Honestly
column18: the biggest flaw I could find on the car was that the in dash clock doesn't work. I called my brother and told him if he didn't buy the car
column19: I would. He lives about an hour away
column20: but he said if I thought it was that nice to buy it and he'd buy it from me.

column1: I got it for the princely sum of $3100. For a super sharp black Maxima SE with automatic
column2: Bose
column3: CD player
column4: cruise
column5: ice cold A/C
column6: moonroof
column7: PW/PL. So little bro got a sweet ride
column8: and I got to scratch the CCB itch...

column2: 2005 12:00PM	guss	"My cutoff to trade or sell outright is about $10k. With a 6% tax credit on the trade it usually is better to just trade it in.

column1: When the price is below $10k you can get the trade credit money and find a buyer more easily on a lower priced car. The price to sell in on my own is usually $1
column2: 000 to $1500 over the dealer trade number. So own a $5k car that credit difference is not as big as on a $12
column3: 000 car.

column1: Either way it ain't cheap unless you buy at the right price to begin with and try not to move too far up in vehicle value."

2005 12:49PM	billherrmann	"IF you're buying a new car and your trade is paid off. You find a buyer for your trade car. you ask the New car dealer to agree to a ""COURTESY TRADE"" . Although the dealers don't like to do it....they will
column3: because the new car deal depends on it. On delivery day
column4: you arrive at dealership with your trade and your buyer. Dealer takes car in trade [and reduces your sales tax accordingly} and SIMALTANESLY sells your trade car to your buyer for the price that you & he agreed to beforehand. Naturally the trade-in $ figure and the Sale $ to the buyer are the same......another benefit to you
column5: since it is higher than wholesale. Dealers HATE to do courtesy trades because they make 00.00 money and it involves more paperwork...but they will
column6: to get the new car sale. I have done it several times myself and every CCBer should learn this. Bill H."

column2: 2005 1:51PM	mark156	"Bill H.
column3: a friend of mine bought a new 2002 C240 sedan at our local Mercedes-Benz dealer and wanted the dealer to do a courtesy trade with his 1998 Lexus ES300 that he was selling to a co-worker. The dealer would not do it. MOST dealers will not do because of one very important thing
column4: it makes them LIABLE.

column1: Terry (the professional) has mentioned this before that dealers will not do this

column1: Have you known a dealer to really do this?

column2: 2005 2:02PM	lemmer	"I wrote a long reply to this yesterday
column3: but the lightning knocked out the power before I could post it. The story goes like this:

column1: An old lady at my Dad's church passed away. Her family decided her car was not worth the trouble of trying to sell (now that I have thought about it a little more
column2: I think it was a '63 or '64). They offered it to me if I would clear it out of the carport. I
column3: of course
column4: jumped at the chance even though I had no use for the car. It was 100% original
column5: but sitting on four flat tires with a dead battery. With a new battery
column6: some judicious use of carb cleaner
column7: four rotted and leaking bias ply tires pumped full of air
column8: and various other cobweb fighting
column9: I drove the car five miles to my Dad's house.

column1: Over time I tuned it up pretty well and found a matching set of used Uniroyal Tiger Paws (it is hard to find really tall 14"" tires nowadays). It had a 361 big block
column2: a push-button transmission
column3: and something like a 2.38 rear end. I would drive it up and down the road next to my Dad's house on the weekends
column4: but not too far as it had a leaking heating core
column5: and not too fast as the brakes were no longer capable of stopping the car. (Does anyone remember in ""Fletch"" when he keeps stopping that huge Cadillac by running into stuff? The brakes were about like that.)

column1: I thought I was going to keep it as a cool weekend hooptie
column2: but my trusted mechanic (and big American iron fan) told me I was crazy. The entire braking system needed to be replaced as all the lines were rotted. He said if I fixed the brakes and started driving the car
column3: I would end up systematically replacing everything mechanical on the car as it was all atrophied from misuse. To add to these problems
column4: my Dad was not happy about having it in his yard. When I finished graduate school
column5: it went to a junkyard.

column1: Bonuses with the car - it came with the original owner's manual and a yardstick in the trunk that had printed on it ""1958 Chevy - Lower
column2: Longer
column3: Wider"" along with the name of a local Chevy dealer. I still have both of those."

column2: course it was really my fault. I kept thinking the Goodyear Eagles would last another 6k........they are running way close to the wear idicators
column3: so I ignored the fact the car was pulling to the left (figured an alignment that could wait) and the fact that the car was shaking violently (figured the tires were just wore out).

column1: Yesterday morning I drove to work at my usual nutty pace (80-90 mph) and arrived safely (if I had only known what I would see 12 hours later). Hubby came in later with the Titan to get parts for the cursed skidder
column2: so I told him I'd drive the Titan home (it IS mine after all). I mentioned that he needed to be careful of Zippy (he rarely drives her) since she was shaking badly.

column1: Right about then I had a gut feeling to look at the driver's side front tire. Ran my hand over it and it seemed ok........gut feeling said NO
column2: LOOK at the tire. Bent down and looked at it
column3: I was beyond stunned. Got on the phone to the used tire place and managed to get 2 used tires put on for $50 right at closing time. The guy said there was NO way the tire would have made it home. Zippy had eaten through the inside half of the tire
column4: through tread
column5: rubber
column6: steel belts
column7: and into the nylon. My brother looked at it and with a little pressure could have put his finger through the tire
column8: the wear showed up on the inside as well.

column2: still shaking some
column3: but no more pulling. She has an appt on Monday for an alignment and front end check. She's still not right
column4: very over reactive on the steering. Not her fault though
column5: twice a day through road construction and gravel has beaten that poor car up badly.

column1: Talk about a reality check! I figure my guardian angels were flying overtime yesterday morning!"

2005 2:18PM	andre1969	"that Honda uses in the Accord has two overdrive gears. 3rd gear is your 1.00:1 ratio (or ""Direct Drive"" as they used to call it in the old days). I think 4th gear is somewhere around 0.75:1 and 5th gear is around 0.52:1.

column1: It has a fairly short axle though
column3: so in 5th gear your OTGR (Overall Top Gear Ratio) is around 2.30:1. Fairly tall and loafy
column4: but not ""super tall"". For instance
column5: back in the late 70's and early 80's
column6: bigger GM cars with 3-speed automatics often had 2.41:1 and even 2.14:1 axles. My '79 NYer has a 2.45:1 rear
column7: and in '81 Chrysler switched all of their V-8 RWD non-police cars to tall 2.26:1 axles.

column2: when 4-speed overdrive trannies started to become popular
column3: family-type cars with the Chevy 305 usually had a 2.56:1 rear
column4: while cars with the Olds 307 usually had a 2.73:1. Overdrive gear on that tranny though is 0.667:1
column5: giving you an OTGR of 1.71:1 on the Chevy and 1.82:1 on the Olds engine. I'd imagine that would be considered pretty tall."

column2: 2005 2:15AM	andre1969	"that Impala has a 2.56:1 rear end. If you go to www.tirerack.com
column3: and look up some tires that are the same size that are on your car
column4: in the specs they list how many revolutions per mile the tires will turn. For instance
column6: which was most likely standard on that car (or they might've cheaped out and put 195/75/R-15s
column7: like Chrysler did on the '79-81 R-bodies) turns 769 rpm. Multiply that by 2.56
column8: and that'll give you the revolutions per mile
column9: which would also happen to be the revolutions per minute at 60 mph. In this case 1969 rpm. To get the rpm@70 mph
column10: just take the 1969 and multiply by 7/6ths
column11: which gives you 2297.

column1: Now I'm sure this isn't an exact calculation
column2: but should give you a pretty close estimate. I'd imagine that the actual rpms of the engine would be a bit higher
column3: due to slippage in the transmission and such
column4: even though these cars probably had a lockup torque convertor by that time.

column2: and here's a little nostalgia trip for you guys... http://www.tocmp.com/brochures/Chev/1979/index.html"

column2: 2005 1:44PM	andre1969	"if it's an Impala or a Caprice is whether or not there's carpeting on the lower door panels. You could get cloth or vinyl in both the Impala and Caprice

column6: they were very close in '78
column7: but the Caprice had kind of an eggcrate grille
column8: with the horizontal bars being about as thick as the vertical bars
column9: while the Impala's grille had three prominent horizontal bars

column1: Impala and Caprice taillights were usually different
column2: too. The Impala usually had the backup light in between the two outer lights. The Caprice usually had three red taillights on either side

column4: but the vast majority of them were 2-bbls. The 350 was only offered as a 4-bbl by that time.

column2: 2005 2:00PM	corvette	"It's funny you mention that... Right after the Freestyle came out
column3: I saw one on the interstate filled up with stuff
column4: and the low-hanging tailpipe was about to drag the ground!

column1: Did I ever post my theory on the 1996-generation Explorer rollovers? This may have no scientific basis
column2: but here goes: I noticed a ton of Explorers that
column3: when traveling at interstate speed
column4: would ""lean"" backwards--the rear end of the truck would squat down close to the ground. Perhaps they were carrying a lot of cargo
column5: but it doesn't make sense
column6: given the number of these that I saw. I suspect that some combination of bad aerodynamics pushed the rear of the car down too hard at high speed
column7: placing more weight than was intended on the rear axle. Carrying rear passengers or cargo would only compound this effect. Perhaps this was intended to provide additional rear traction and stability to prevent oversteer
column8: but became dangerous when the car was loaded down. With the rear axle loaded down in this manner
column9: the tires are probably above their weight limits at the recommended pressure (26 psi?)
column10: and are being subjected to more impact harshness and stress when driving over pockmarked pavement due to the reduced suspension travel caused by the loading of the live rear axle. This is the perfect recipe for overloading and blowing out a rear tire
column11: which is very likely to result in a loss of control. Also
column12: the lack of downward force on the front end of the car would make it much harder to steer
column13: making it easier to lose control...

column2: did I earn my pseudo-expert witness badge with that? :P"

column1: 2004 GMC Sierra 2500HD Crew Cab The ultimate family truckster. In spring '04 I had a '99 Exploder V8. a '95 29' Motorhome
column2: and an open car trailer
column3: to do regular family of 4 car and weekend duty. The Exploder was costing $500-1000 to fix semi-regularly on stupid quality related stuff. (Ball Joints
column4: Steering Rack
column5: etc.). The RV was making me nervous on having even more expensive things go wrong with it. And the open car trailer was a PIT* to load and unload. So the household CFO gave me pemission to Sell Everything. After the RV went (for almost what I paid for it 3 years prior!)
column6: we bought this truck. Since we didn't need or want a third seat
column7: the pick-up does what we need well
column8: and I don't have to worry about dirtying up the back. Just hose it out. It has a 1-ton chassis and running gear
column9: and even with only the 6.0 gas motor
column10: tows my new 8000lb all loaded up enclosed trailer just fine at 70 mph
column11: getting 9-9.5 mpg
column12: which isn't all that bad. Around town
column13: it gets the same as the Exploder. Oh
column14: and 0% for 60 months. Can't beat free money
column15: though I don't want to know how upside down I probably am 15 months into the deal. My wife daily drives this
column16: and loves being the queen of the soccer fields. This one will stay around a while.

column1: So that leaves me to my next purchase
column2: which currently has me leaning in the direction of am '03-'05 E46 BMW 330i
column3: with the ZHP Performance Package. More hp
column4: higher redline
column5: better suspension
column6: and shorter rear gears. This may be a tugh find
column7: but I like the pre-Bangle cars' looks better. A 2 year old example CPO should be a somewhat reasonable deal too. I plan on having fun looking."

2005 5:41PM	andre1969	"it's 24x40 feet overall (not counting the T-111 siding). One the inside
column3: it ends up being 22'10"" x 39'2"" inside the 4x6 poles. It uses pole barn construction
column4: versus the regular type of framing that the typical garage or house uses
column5: and is supposed to be cheaper than frame construction.

column1: I never did price a frame building
column2: though
column3: so I don't have anything to go by as a reference. Back in 2003 my Mom and stepdad had a 24x28 garage built and it ended up costing around $19
column4: 000 for everything. That included a brick front
column5: vinyl siding
column6: electricity
column7: nicer windows (mine are kinda trailer park-ish
column8: although they look like they're actually double-pane) and a 9 foot interior height...I think mine will come in at a bit over 8 feet once the slab's poured.

column2: my Mom is in a different county
column3: and their garage was built by Mennonites or Amish or some similar group that tends to charge a lower labor rate. And I'm sure labor rates and construction materials have gone up since 2003
column4: especially with the housing boom and such. I've heard that concrete in particular has really skyrocketed.

column2: I'm happy with it. Originally I was going to go with a 30x40 gambrel barn with a loft
column3: but the county shot that one down real fast. They have a silly little restriction here that no secondary buildings can have more square footage than the primary structure. This 30x40 building would've had 1200 square feet (thy didn't count the loft) but they only had my house down as having 1106 square feet. It's actually more like 1500
column4: but they don't count my enclosed side porch
column5: and they consider it a 1 1/2 story
column6: so they only count half of the upstairs square footage.

column1: They also had a height restriction of 15 feet for any secondary buildings. However
column2: on cape cod style buildings
column3: they took the measurement half way up the roof. On gambrel style buildings
column4: they'd take the measurement where the steeper plane of the roof meets the flatter plane
column5: which on my original plan came in at 17 feet. So back to the drawing board I went!

column2: the second time I went in to apply for the permit
column3: using the plans for the building I have now
column4: they told me that they changed the way they measure height. Turns out too many people were building cape cods and then bumping the upstairs out with massive dormers
column5: in effect making a complete second story. So they just gave up and decided to change the height cap to 20 feet. By that time though
column6: I was fed up enough that I wasn't about to go and get a THIRD design drawn up! :mad:

column1: I don't think electricity will be too hard to do after the fact
column2: because the inside of the garage is just a shell
column3: so it's not like there's any drywall to tear out or anything. The worst part would probably be having to dig a trench from the house all the way down to the garage to run the electric. But then
column4: there's a utility pole about 90 feet from the garage
column5: out at the street
column6: so it may be worth it to just run a separate meter/circuit breaker box and just not have it tie into the house at all."

column3: she's gonna think she died and went to car heaven......only a 52 mile round trip commute now. Still a great car at 50k miles and 15 months old.

column2: the Titan is doing fine
column3: seems like the harder I push the truck the less problems we have. Well
column4: we'll see about that when it has to pull 9k+ next weekend.........poor truck!

column1: As for the amount of trailers we have.......no
column2: we don't collect them
column3: they all have their purpose. We have an old (73 F100) pickup bed trailer which hubby drags with him to get firewood. We have the 18' trailer which will come in handy at times. We have the new 12' dump trailer (read: save the back during unloading) which hubby will probably pull for the most part in place of the old pickup bed trailer. Then we have the travel trailer (yard ornament for the winter).

column1: Now the fun part.........we thought we were soooo smart buying that dump trailer
column2: but the first day with it wasn't exactly a picnic. By the time hubby got to the logging road he had lost turn signals and brake lights on his truck
column3: he went ahead and took the trailer in to the landing
column4: loaded it
column5: and headed out to make the delivery. He gets to the customer's house and hits the button to dump the trailer
column6: it goes up fine
column7: but he sees something near the hydralic pump.......bends over and about passes out from the smell of burning wires. The trailer melted its wiring. Got it dumped and back down
column8: then came home.

column1: I took the trailer back to the dealer today
column2: they found the problems (factory forgot to put the ground wire on)
column3: and rewired the trailer. The owner told us if we have ANY more problems she will replace the trailer with a new one. She did call the bank to see what was involved (a bunch of paperwork) and decided to have her guys fix it
column4: then go from there. So far so good
column5: it didn't blow any fuses on the Titan so I think its ok. :shades:"

column2: 2005 1:04AM	andre1969	"jjtj
column3: I'm not sure what Chrysler called that leather in the New Yorker. It was part of a special package that they called the 5th Avenue edition (instead of being its own model
column4: the 5th Ave used to be one of those designer-type packages
column5: like a Bill Blass Lincoln
column6: I guess) that added about $1500 to the base price of the New Yorker. The 5th Ave also added the Driftplood accents on the inside
column7: fake vents on the fenders
column8: and a ""Fifth Avenue"" script in the opera windows that lit up at night. It also had those dorky wire wheels
column9: which are now in one of my sheds...I have copcar wheels and little dog-dish hubcaps on it now! I'm guessing they just called the leather ""Designers Leather"" or something dumb like that. I remember the color scheme is called ""Designer Creme"" over ""Designer Beige"" How original.

column1: And I'm the same way when it comes to looking at houses...the first thing I look for is how big the garage is
column2: and if there's enough room to add on to it! One of my friends has a townhouse with a garage that barely holds his Passat. Well
column3: he recently went out and bought a Mark V. Needless to say
column4: it won't fit! :surprise: And I guess this garage shows where my priorities are...the house could really use a new roof
column5: new windows
column6: paint
column7: and a whole bunch of other work
column8: and yet I focus on the garage!

column2: the reason they were able to build the garage this way
column3: before a complete foundation is poured
column4: is because technically it's a pole barn. Here's a drawing of the footer plan for it
column5: that I had to have an engineer draw up after the drilling crew ended up hitting groundwater on just about every single hole. Originally they were just going to pour 8 inches of concrete in the bottom
column6: but the new plan called for digging the holes deeper
column7: putting in 12"" of gravel
column8: and then 12"" of concrete. As for building the garage then
column9: the crew just set the poles in
column10: and as they started nailing up the sides that connected the poles
column11: it ultimately stabilized itself. They also poured a little bit of concrete around the poles to hold them in place
column12: because I guess it could flex a bit otherwise
column13: if a strong enough wind hit it.

column2: about how they're going to get more gravel in there to level the floor off though
column3: and then pour the concrete
column4: but the man doing it said it should be no sweat! I just hope he's right!

column2: I'm glad SOMEONE thinks my collection of cars is neat. Would you guys like to come over sometime and try to convince my family to my way of thinking? :P"
2005 3:31AM	stickguy	just curious
column3: but it seems like the barn (err
column4: garage) is awfully far from the house. Did you put it way out because you wanted it far away

column2: 2005 4:53AM	andre1969	"Lemme guess? Powers That Be? They had some say in where I put the garage
column3: but I decided from the get-go that I wanted it down that far in the yard. It's about 150 feet from the steps to my deck. But I kinda like it down there
column4: because it's out of the way. It also makes the yard feel bigger
column5: being down there kind of at the edge of the yard
column6: although it's actually still about 50 feet from the property line on that side.

column1: The county made me put it 90 feet back from the road
column2: though. Originally
column3: I wanted to make it 60 feet back. I was under the impression you only had to be 25 feet back from the road
column4: and 15 feet from your neighbors' property line. But then I found out that 25 feet is only for the main house. Any secondary detached buildings have to be at least 60 feet back. But to make matters worse
column5: the county has it on their books that they want 30 feet of my land for a right-of-way to expand the road! :mad: They'll either get it over my dead body
column6: but I'm really not that concerned about it...supposedly it's been on the books since the 70's
column7: and most likely the only way the road would get widened would be if a developer came through and bought up me and all the neighbors tore it all down
column8: and put up a development. And then I wouldn't care
column9: because we'd all be paid off and gone! But anyway
column10: they tacked that 30 feet onto the 60 foot requirement
column11: making me put it back 90 feet. I ended up having to take down about 5 or 6 trees that were growing up at the edge of the woods
column12: some of them leaning outward
column13: and had to clear out a lot of brush. So
column14: to make up for that
column15: I'm going to let some of the yard out towards the road grow back up and plant some trees here and there...just not too close to the garage!

column2: the house is either going to get moved or torn down and replaced
column3: and when that time comes
column4: the site I want to build on will be down closer to the garage. So that's another reason I put it that far down
column5: so it wouldn't be practically up against the house when that time comes."

column2: 2005 12:11AM	downhomeinga	"Long time lurker - First time poster here!

column1: I seem to have fallen into the habit of buying my co-workers old cars - often in non-running condition.

About 6 months ago bought a 91 Mazda 626 (I have a thing for older Mazda's - just one aspect of my sickness) loaded (but non-turbo) edition with a 5 speed. Kinda beaten up (kids) with 142K miles and numerous deferred maintenance issues. My co-worker had given up on it when the drivers window would no longer close. Then her husband shattered the window trying to force it closed. She parked it in her garage for 8 months until she decided to sell her house - then she had to get rid of it. Of course by then it did not run - so no one was interested in it.

column2: put a new battery in it and did a basic tune up and fluid change in her driveway. It started right up and I drove it home (50 miles) with no problems. Since then have probably put another $500 in it (and too much of my own time). Been using it as a parts getter and lifeboat.

column1: Kinda feel a little guilty about this transaction
column2: but hey it's a 14 year old car that has been beaten on and still has a few issues after my fixes above.

column1: Thoughts on the guilt aspect of CCBA? Or the family/spouse related guilt?"

column2: 2005 12:26AM	downhomeinga	"I apologize in advance for the long post - but I need therapy - and luckily I found CCBA!

column1: Then there is car #2 - purchased two weeks ago from another co-worker. A 1997 Maxima SE loaded with 162K miles in immaculate condition (dealer maintained since new). Co-worker overheated the car on the way home and had it towed in to a service station (that I had warned her did not sound reputable based on her prior experiences). They refill the radiator and do a pressure test - diagnosis blown head gasket due to the car continuing to overheat (but only at speed - not at idle).
They want $3300 to install a used motor. I am advising her all along that this does not sound like a blown head to me
column2: but a cooling flow issue. Advise her to get a second opinion at a radiator shop nearby.

column1: By this point she has full blown new car fever and has told the mechanic that she may be willing to sell the car as is. He offers her $600. I tell her that if she is going to go that route that I will double his offer to $1200. Again
column2: advising her that I think she has a general cooling system problem - not a major engine issue. And further
column3: that if I had some time with the car I could likely fix it for her for a few hundred in parts.

column2: gives up on the Maxima and sells it to me for $1200. Before I buy it
column3: I tell her I am concerned that she will be mad if I fix it cheaply/easily. She says she is not concerned.

column2: hoses
column3: thermostat) and 2 hours later I have it back on the road.

column2: I tell her that I think I have it fixed and tell her what I did/what it cost.

column1: Her response? ""Good for you! Better you than some unscrupulous mechanic!""
Still feeling kinda guilty driving such a nice car that I got from such a nice lady/friend for $1500.
Should I feel guilty? Or is this just my overactive ""southern gentleman"" gene kicking in?"

column2: 2005 3:25AM	ghulet	You saved her $3300 on the new engine and $600 on the purchase
column3: the car is nine years old and sounds like she wanted one anyway. You got a great deal
column4: she's not angry (she would have no grounds to be anyway) and she has a new car. No harm

column2: 2005 5:30PM	mark156	"Hi folks
column3: I've been ""car looking"" for several weeks and will probably buy in early December. This is what I have been researching:

column2: my conclusion is that the Land Rover has moved to the top where it was at the bottom a week ago. My requirements are that the vehicle must seat 6 or more people
column3: have adequate power
column4: AWD or 4x4 and have full sun visors that adjust once you move them to the side.

column1: Note: I have not driven any of these vehicles yet.
*The Land Rover appears to have the most room inside
column2: does not have adjustable sun visors but they are very large and it might work with a slight adjustment in the seat to keep the sun from hitting the side of your face. One complaint was that the dash looked very ""plasticy"" but Land Rover offers a wood kit for the dash that looked quite attractive. The third seat will fit a 6'2"" person comfortably.

column1: *All Volvo's have Non-Adjusting short sun visors. The headrests in the XC90 are not comfortable. (The plus)The third seats fold completely flat and I like the split flip gate and small tail gate configuration like the Land Rover.
*The Volvo wagon's third seat is ONLY for small children so this one is not in the running.
*The Jeep Commander was at the top of the list but now I don't care for the third seat set-up where the floor is raised 3 inches to accomodate the folding seats. Also
column2: I don't care for the 'bolt screws' that are apparent all over the vehicle
column3: on the dash
column4: in the headlight assembly's and around the fender wheel-wells. I like to wash my vehicles myself and I keep thinking I'm going to have to keep a supply of Q-tips handy for cleaning the crevices. Also
column5: for such a large vehicle
column6: the second and third row are rather tight. The front passenger seat is only a 4-way power adjust (the bottom of the seat does not move up and down). For a $44
column7: 000 vehicle it should have 8-way power seats.

column1: * The Cadillac SRX is a nicely done vehicle. The sun visors don't fully adjust and are short. Third seat is a little small.
*The Mercedes R500 is nice but too ""mini-vanish"" for me and it's $15
column2: 000 more than the Land Rover and will seat only 6 vs 7 for the LR3.

column1: These are basically visual and personal observations on how the vehicle will fit my needs. I know that the performance will vary some with each drivetrain/engine size. They all basically get the same fuel mileage which is about 14-15 in the city and 18-20 on the highway.

column4: hmmm ...

column3: that's another 140K that I've driven.

Should there be a Chronic Car Drivers Anonymous?"

2005 4:05PM	anonymousposts	is a usage tax if I am not mistaken so trading your car would not lower this tax. Sales tax is only paid on the vehicle if you buy out the lease. If you trade it in the dealer can deduct what the tax would be for you to buy it thus making their payoff lower than what you would pay. If you think of it in terms of sales tax it actually benefits you to lease it. Depending on what the sales tax is in your state it could save you $1000+ on a $20
column3: 000 car. Since your car is paid for the dealer would have to cut you a check back for the value of the tC. If you do decide to lease it may pay to sell the car on your own or shop it around at local dealers (maybe Carmax if you have one close to you) and get the most money possible. Considering the popularity of the car and the low miles on yours it might be most beneficial to sell it private owner to a parent buying their child a Christmas present.
